text: It's not the best part of town and probably never was. A  place of seedy, anonymous brick flophouses shackled by ru fire escapes, lying on an alley unique only for its bad  drainage. It's here, in the dim, flinty light, that a fig enters. Wearing a long coat and, despite the night, sunglasses, h pauses on the slimy asphalt and gazes up the sides of the flophouses, to their yellowish windows and competing Mexi radio stations. One window, dark and quiet on the third f catches his gaze. There's a metal hand railing in the alley that the long-c figure effortlessly pops up onto. Sunglasses focused on t window, he lowers himself into a motionless crouch, a per on the railing with the ease of a crow. Or a gargoyle.

Dawn is a muddled, limp thing that does nothing to improv the alley. The figure is still there, a motionless gargoy perched on the railing. Watching the window. The shadows shorten, the air grows warmer, and now there' movement behind the window. The sunglassed gargoyle drops down off the railing, jumps to the first rung of the fire escape, and begins climbing

Is a room as grim as we expect. Lumpy iron bed, sink that been pissed into one too many times, and SIMON; a man in tight sweater and dark sunglasses, busily emptying his po on the ruined dresser: loose change, a town paper's obitu column. Simon's sunglassed eyes look up suddenly, his body  stifffening. He whips around to face the window just as i EXPLODES into fragments. The gargoyle LEAPS into the room on the trail of glass. S spins and THROWS himself against the intruder. The two  STRUGGLE savagely across the room, SMASHING chairs. Simon manages a grip on the gargoyle's face and POUNDS th back of his skull against the wall. The gargoyle gets his locked fists up and SWINGS them like a war club, SMACKING Simon's face and SPRAWLING him backwards onto the bed. The two, across the room for each other, pause.
Where is it?
Simon's climbed to his feet, the two men in sunglasses no walking slow circles around each other.
Leave me alone.
You've found it, haven't you?
Fuck you.

The gargoyle drops his head and DRIVES himself into Simon who HAMMERS the gargoyle with his fists. Blood SMEARS. The gargoyle's gotten free a knife that he JAMS into Simo leg. Pressing home his advantage, the gargoyle SLAMS Simo up against the wall. He TEARS open Simon's shirt, digging his fingers into the chest, RIPPING the skin aside, the f plunging deep, CRACKING the sternum bone, pushing even  further, toward the blood gouged pumping beneath -- -- Simon PLOWS his knee up between the gargoyle's legs. O and over. Till the grip loosens and Simon SHOVES him to o side, using the momentum and drives to SWING the body aro and at the shattered window. The gargoyle SMACKS the fram and COLLAPSES, his head CRACKING on the sill and FORCING shard of glass through his neck. Simon moves to the window and brushes aside the gargoyle' sunglasses, revealing two totally empty eye sockets. Push his thumbs into them, Simon uses the leverage to lift the gargoyle off the sill and push his body out the window. The gargoyle bounces once on the fire escape, then spread eagles thirty feet to the asphalt. Somebody turns up their Mexican radio station. The gargoyle's a wreck. But he manages, slowly -- his shattered remains arguing e inch -- to climb first to his knees, then miserably to hi feet. A bent, splattered, hopeless thing that manages to  stumble three or four feet before being HIT by a freeway- speed firebird BOMBING down the alley. The impact PINS the gargoyle to the grill and RAMS him in a brick wall, CRUSHING a chest that BELCHES out a sickly, bruised heart like a wet rag against the firebird's  windshield.

Simon leans against his splintered window and looks down the pinned and very finished body of the gargoyle. His ow shirt and pants are a mess of torn blood and his breathin is difficult. Pain flashes across his forehead as he chec that his own sunglasses still sit snugly on the bridge of his nose. At the sound of a distant siren Simon turns and quickly  finishes packing his duffle bag. Stiffly pulling on an  oversize surplus army jacket that partly conceals the dam beneath, he picks up the bag and painfully shuffles out.

The gargoyle, still pinned to the wall by the firebird. A FLASH bounces off his skin. Then another. He's being  photographed. Go wide and find him in the middle of a pol investigation. Bored blue uniforms, yellow barrier tape. usual. A plain jane sedan pulls up and deposits THOMAS DAGGET,  thirties, tweed coat and steel notebook. He smiles at a c of cops, ducks under the yellow barrier, and nods a greet to an older uniform sergeant, BURROWS.
Hey.
Hey.
(looks up at sky) Thought those clouds this morning  spelled rain for sure, but it's turned  into a beautiful day, wouldn't you  say, Sergeant Burrows?
Thomas takes a deep, healthy breath. Burrows just stares him.
I warned you about that cheerful  shit.
Sorry. I'm working on it.
He eyes finally make their way to the gargoyle.
What's the word?
Friend here did a half-gainer with a  firebird tuck from the third floor.
Jumper?
Not unless he decided not to bother  opening the window first.
Drugs? Alcohol?
Well, he wasn't exactly in a condition  to walk a chalk line when we got  here. You're welcome to try and smell  his breath if you like, that is if  you can find the mouth.
Ghouls been by?
On their way. Willie promises a white  paper tomorrow. Or Wednesday,  depending on his golf game.
Firebird driver?
Burrows nods in the direction of a very shook up young ma sitting on the curb.
Mr. Jiminez. Was taking a short cut  to his job at a packing plant on San  Pedro. First thing he remembers about  the deceased is several vital organs  bouncing off his windshield.
Have you had him walk a chalk line?
He's straight. Shook up some.
(looking at gargoyle) Anything on him?
No wallet, license, nothing. He is  missing one or two things, though.
Like?
His eyes.
(looking at tangled  mess) Along with everything else.
We've found everything else -- and  what fun that was, let me tell you --  but the eyes are still AWOL. Might  just be stuck in the radiator grill.  Little weird though.
What?
Both popping out together like that.  Worth a page in my scrapbook.
Burrows and Thomas coming up the stairs.
Who's the room registered under?
John Smith.
Anything interesting inside?
There are, what an intelligent,  experienced detective like yourself  could possibly construe as signs of  a struggle.
They enter the room, which is, of course, totally trashed Thomas steps over the splintered furniture.
Naturally nobody saw or heard  anything.
In such a fine establishment as this?
Thomas looks at the splashes of blood, overturned dresser a newspaper, the "Chimney Rock Republican"; one name in i obit section circled. Burrows sighs and checks his watch.
Ku San's on fourteenth is still open  for another hour. Whatd'ya say we  pull out the 'ol "SUICIDE" rubber  stamp and get some lunch. Rancid  chow mein and watered beer for under  three bucks.
(looking at floor) There's glass in the carpet.
That usually happens when you break  a window.
It's on the inside.
Amongst the glass fragments at Thomas' feet is a pair of  dark sunglasses. He picks them up, taps them in his palm, and looks out the window down to the man with no eyes, pi between brick and chrome.
Where's Chimney Rock?
Arizona desert, I think. Which is  exactly where I'm going to be in two  years, three months.
And give up all this?
You're breaking my heart.

The sun sinking beneath the horizon of a vast and undulat expanse of desert. Travel through the landscape as the sky purples and darke and silhouettes tall, finger-like spires of volcanic rock Hear the coyotes, the wind making its constant, probing  search. Before the night swallows it all whole, Come upon The Town. It used to be something. But that's long gone. Now, wrapp in the sucking blackness of a wilderness night, it's a sh of a place. Lights still burn in some of the windows but fool no one. The ghosts are the majority here. Biding their time. Wait for The Town to surrender and slip beneath the waves of t desert. The wind slinks over the hills, creeps down past boarded- storefronts, skeletal ocitillo, and the rusting hulks of  abandoned mining equipment. The corpse of a summer's kite twists slowly on a power line.
From the inky oblivion of the road, comes a crunch of gra

head_text.subj: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF TOWN

text: Stands a large, nineteenth century brick schoolhouse. An  icon from a more prosperous past, its dark massiveness wa meant for scores of ruddy-faced miner's kids. Now it seem to be imploding, eating itself with creeping decay. On th night it is silent and dark but for a small glow in one c and the faint sound of children's voices in song. It is a hymn. An ancient, Latin one. The melancholy beaut of voices rising and falling in choir.

Is a school auditorium. On the stage, dwarfed by it, are  twenty five students from first grade to high school, sin together as a choir. A young woman, KATHERINE, directs th acapella voices as the small group of parents, lonely in huge room, look on.
The voices drift on the night, down the road, and lap aga the peeling facade of a storefront. A mortuary.
The rooms are dark but for one. There, bathed in the  flickering light of a tall candle, lies the body of the o general we saw at the opening.
Of the mortuary has a locked handle that jiggles from out A small panes of glass beside it is BROKEN by a hand.

Young voices struggle with the complicated hymn and its p of centuries. Faces white, Mexican, Navaho. Katherine gui them with soft hands. She smiles in pride. They smile bac Proud. Of her. Of themselves and the beauty coming from t mouths. One small, beautiful navaho girl, MARY, maybe eight, gets special smile of special friendship from Katherine.
Front door now stands ajar in the darkness. Small shards glass glisten in the carpet.

Is the dead General. Even in the bleached ravages of age death, his face still holds a shadow of vigor and pride. It takes a moment in the weak flicker of the candle to re someone is there with him. Simon in his oversized surplus jacket. His arms are folded tightly across his middle, as in deep cold. But his gaunt face is moist with sweat and breath is shallow and uneven. He stares at the old man be sunglasses and takes slow, cautious steps forward into th amber glow. Holding out two blood-stained fingers, Simon touches the  General's forehead. A new strain crosses his perspiring f Concentration. Placing his right palm on the General's chin and the left his forehead, Simon CRACKS OPEN the dead man's mouth.
The hymn is reaching its aching climax of medieval longin
Simon leans down to the open mouth, and in a voice soft a deeply weary,
Qui ex Patre Flioque procedit...
Then, with the school choir distant and faint in the nigh the living man places his mouth over that of the dead man
It's coffee and cake now as parents proudly hug their chi and congratulate their young teacher. Even in this gloomy crumbling building it's a warm, small town moment.
Simon has left the mortuary and now limps with difficulty through the silent streets, leaning against shop walls fo support.

Through the doors out steps the eight year old Navaho gir Mary. Alone, she stands on the stone stairs and looks out into the night with sensitive eyes. She concentrates. Kno Katherine follows her out.
Hey bright eyes, what's the deal  being out here all alone without a  coat?
The girl's eyes seem too serious for a child's. Too  perceptive.
Someone's here.
Katherine looks out into the night.
Where?
Mary stares a moment longer, then becomes a child again,  smiling and popping Katherine one on the arm.
Pig out on all the cake?
Oh, there might be one, tiny, skinny  piece left, but you're gonna have to  race me for it.
Mary suddenly points past Katherine's shoulder.
What's that?
When Katherine turns Mary dashes back into the building.
Ha!
You little sneak!
Katherine chases after her.
Simon comes limping up from the road. His breathing's bad now as he moves stiffly along the school's brick walls, c to an old, rusty back door he creaks open and slides thro

He climbs a littered and disused staircase, past broken b bottles and condom wrappers to a dark and creaky second f It's part of the school building long abandoned. Doors to classrooms lie half off their hinges, windows are broken, rats squeak between ancient desks stacked like funeral py Simon, his breath echoing in the cold darkness, shuffles  along the broken linoleum till he comes to a rectangle cu in the wall where a row of lockers used to be. He crawls  into the space and there, surrounded by rot, curls up on  himself and sucks his thumb.
Thomas Dagget's eyes opening slowly. He sits up in his be runs a hand through his hair, and looks out with only med enthusiasm at the morning.

Thomas lights an offering candle and kneels for a brief,  silent prayer. He crosses himself, stands, and walks for door. Before leaving he glances back at the altar. A  questioning moment between two akward, estranged friends.
Thomas sits at his desk half-heartily trying to make sens of the three dozen files piled there. Lt. Paul, his boss, leans against a wall nearby.
How's it going?
I was just looking for my "SUICIDE"  rubber stamp.
Sorry about leaving you without a  partner. Everything's up in the air  till the commission settles their  manpower budget.
I'm okay. (his phone rings) Dagget... It's done already? (smiles) Must have rained over the golf course  this morning. I'll be right over.
A set of golf clubs rest forelornly in the corner. An  irritable looking coroner fumes behind his desk as Thomas enters.
Hey, Willie, sorry to hear about the  weather.
The coroner just stares at him.
Should I bother sitting?
Sit.
Thomas obeys as the coroner spreads out a stack of white  sheets.
Where would you like me to start?
I think we can skip the cause of  death.
All right. To begin with, your man  has no eyes.
Weren't stuck in the radiator grill?
No, he never had any eyes. We checked  the sockets. There's no optic nerve,  muscle pores, loose viscus, nothing.
Huh.
We also did a toxicology on his blood:  High sodium, elevated selenium, no  floating cholesterol platelets, trace  ammonia.
Something wrong with that?
No, it's actually pretty common --  for an aborted fetus.
(rubs eyes) I should have listened to Burrows...
We also did a bone section. Wasn't  that much trouble since most of them  were sticking out of his chest anyway.
And?

When babies grow up their bones get  larger by adding calcium layers over  the interior haversham canals. Child  growth isn't uniform though, comes  in spurts that always leave growth  rings in the bone. Everybody has  them -- except your man. That would,  to a hasty observer, seem to indicate  he had never been a child.
I assume you, a cautious and learned  observer, of course have an  explanation.
Not even remotely. Want to hear the  last one?
Not even remotely.
He's a hermaphrodite. (Thomas stares at him) -- Has both male and female sex  organs.
Think of the possibilities.
Yeah, you can be impotent and frigid  all at the same time -- they don't  normally work.
Thomas sighs and climbs to his feet.
Well, I'd love to say thank you, but --
Oh, I also have a bonus prize for  you.
The coroner opens his desk and pulls out a small, ancient looking leather bound book.
Found this sealed in his coat lining.
Thomas turns it over in his hand.
It's a bible.
A pretty old one, I think.
Thomas runs his finger across the gold-leaf cover.
We checked it out inside. Thought  there might be a name or fingerprint  somewhere. All we found was a curled  page marking the fourteenth chapter  of St. John's Revelations.
There is no fourteenth chapter to  Revelations.
Maybe this is the teacher's edition.
Thomas opens the bible and there it is, in Latin, the  fourteenth chapter.
Can I keep this awhile?
Sure.
(beat) Can you sit on all this a few days,  Willie? Not circulate the file? I  need some time before all the  questions start.
Oooh, are we breaking the rules again?
So what else is new?

Thomas at his desk, working under a lone gooseneck lamp.  He's translating the fourteenth chapter of St. John's  Revelations from Latin onto a slip of paper. Finished, he sets the ancient bible down, turns off the gooseneck, and leans back in his chair, alone in the dark.

Here, outside The Town, horizons are distant, faraway thi The sky overhead is streaked red and blue with barely mor as the screen door of a simple stucco house swings open.  It's Katherine, the teacher. Wearing levis and boots, she carries a saddle swung over one denim shoulder out to a c behind the house where a horse shuffles and whinnies  impatiently.
In a minute, in a minute...
Katherine throws the saddle over the horse and cinches it down as the sun, still tucked behind pink and grey cliffs begins to heat up the sky.

Deep and narrow, an idyllic canyon of compressed sandston walls smoothed, rounded and etched by centuries of wind. tiny creek flows past weak banks of scrub pine and pocked sycamore. A silent place a long way and a long time from  anything but the approach of galloping hooves. Katherine and her horse run full-out through the canyon, clack and splash of hooves echoing off steep, shadowed wa Horse and rider drive each other harder and harder, their hot breath brief clouds in the arch, thin desert air. Boulders shattered by winter cold and summer heat, deep w cut caves hiding scorpions, sidewinders, or a wary mounta lion all pass as in a blur; arrogant hawks and patient  buzzards, ruins of thousand year old Anasazi villages hig on the cliffs, their weather-beaten skulls, seen and unse staring out; everything is one smear of color and smell a Katherine gallops past them and up the cliff trail, out o the canyon, and onto the main plateau.

Katherine strokes her horse and feeds it a bag of carrots She pulls a thermos from the pack, sits down against some old man rocks, and with the coffee steaming in her hand,  greets the sun now cresting the Chuska Mountains. There's a rutted, silty dirt road nearby. An ancient, bat school bus rattles its way past and stops. The bus driver Navaho, JOHN, climbs down and rubbing the side of his hea painfully walks up to Katherine.
You could save my life with some  coffee.
He holds out an empty cup Katherine fills. Sipping painfu he lays down beside her and pulls the brim of his basebal cap over his eyes.
Tough night?
You don't want to hear about it. (peeks out hopefully) Or maybe you do.
No thanks.
Just checking.
The bus is full of young school kids.
Shouldn't they be getting to school?
Impromptu field trip. I'm broadening  their minds. And sparing them the  sight of their beloved chauffeur  barfing his guts out.
Katherine's horse snorts.
I hate horses. How was the canyon?  Honey-suckle out yet?
Didn't see any.
I hate that canyon. I hate this this  whole plateau. Too many goddamn  ghosts. Leave it to them I say. San  Diego, that's where I'm going. Or  Oxnard. I like the sound of that. Ox- nard.
I'm happy here.
Oh lord protect us, another romantic  pale face in love with the desert.
Just got to give it a chance.
Try growing up here. (tries word out on  tongue) Ox-nard. (sticks out coffee  cup) Uno mas, see-boo-play. (she pours) Speaking of romantic pale faces, the  rumor mill is in high gear again.
Who this time?
That funny looking guy from Window  Rock. The BIA lawyer.
(non-committal) Huh.
No! Say it isn't so!
It isn't so.
Thank you.
He finishes the coffee and climbs painfully to his feet.
Thanks for the joe.
No prob.
You're a credit to the community.
He shuffles back to the bus.
All right children, looks sharp!  This is a school day! And no talking  loud!
The bus coughs alive and crawls forward. Katherine waves the faces behind glass, then settles back for a last mome of peace as silence lays again over the land.
Showered and changed into her teaching clothes, Katherine climbs into a rattling pickup.

Katherine drives to work, passing on the outskirts the cl copper mine, vast and abandoned. Down beyond the fading m street lies the great crumbling brick pile that is the sc Katherine parks her truck, grabs her leather bag, and wal in.

Katherine's lecturing her students. All twenty-five of th There's high school age sons of white ranchers, Navaho gi on the edge of puberty, tiny Mexican children. All being  taught together in one room. It's dinosaur day. Katherine has a large fossilized bone her lap.
This is "Camposaurus". Camposaurus  was a herbavore, which meant he only  ate plants. Camposaur stayed mostly  to himself and never bothered anyone.
The little girls smile. They like Camposaurus. Katherine  holds up another bone fragment.
This is a leg fragment that belongs  to the killer of the plateau,  Alosaurus. Alosaurus was a vicious  carnivore, which meant he'd eat  anything that moved, especially nice,  juicy Camposaurs.
The little boys grin. They like Alosaurus.

Both these guys lived together right  here on the White Rock plateau eighty  million years ago, when this area  used to be on the banks of a huge,  shallow sea. Remember how we talked  about how sedimentation fossilizes  bones? That's also what made the  hills out behind our town and put  the copper in the ground.
Lot of good that did us.
Katherine lifts off the desk an ancient 1950s gieger coun and switches it on. It ticks softly when she points it at the dino bone.
It's radioactive! Like Godzilla!
Just a tiny bit, Alex. Do you know  why? Uranium, that's the rock they  use in nuclear power plants --
And bombs!

And bombs Alex, yes, is all through  these hills naturally. Millions of  years ago the dinosaurs here ate  plants and drank water which had  uranium in it that became concentrated  in their bones, which is exactly  how, with Mr. Geiger counter here,  we're going to find some.
The class CHEERS.

With the brick schoolhouse tiny in the background, Kather class trudges its way up the barren, rocky hillside behin the town. The teenage rancher's kids try to make time wit the Mexican girls One of the little boys has gotten into shoving match with a little girl.
(coming between them) -- Hey. Come on. What's the deal,  Brian?
The girl folds her arms defiantly. The boy is pissed,  embarrassed.
She...
Yes?
...She, she called me a "Dick Head".
Sandra?
Well, he is.
All right, Brian. You get one free  insult. Make it good.
Brian concentrates.
You... You're a... Cow Demon!
(beat) Uh... Okay. Everybody satisfied? (looks at Brian) Cow Demon?
Katherine's given the geiger counter to the little Navaho girl, Mary. Focusing grimly on the rock in front of her,  Mary guides the detector over the stones till suddenly it begins clicking softly.
I got one! I got one!
The high school kids come up and help dig.
Easy... Easy... Don't break it.

Almost immediately, an eye socket appears in the dust. As the students carefully brush away the dust, Katherine  looks back across the crumbly path. A coyote has crept up onto a near ledge. It just stands there. Watching her.

It's mostly empty at this time of day and the young man  sitting in the pew, staring at the altar, is alone. His n is GABRIEL and he wears jeans, a faded leather jacket, an dark sunglasses, even inside. His thin hair is slicked ba and there's an almost feminine quality about him. He sits there a moment longer, staring, then gets up and  leaves.
The alley from the beginning. Gabriel pulls his old,  convertible rambler to a stop and walks into the flophous
He comes upstairs to the landing, where the door to the r is covered with a strip of yellow tape: POLICE INVESTIGAT DO NOT ENTER. Gabriel pulls the tape aside and KICKS the door open.

It's still the disaster we remember. Gabriel walks slowly through the room. He scratches up some blood, tastes it. There's spray-painted outlines where the police have remo certain items. Gabriel takes note of this, tastes the blo again, and leaves.
It's lunch break. Most of the students sit in loose cliqu around the front of the building; eating, skipping rope,  picking fights.

The recently unearthed skull sits on Katherine's desk. Fe up beside it, she leans back in her chair looking through dinosaur book. One of her students, a twelve year old boy finishes cleaning up the floor and stands beside her.
I'm all done with the cleaning, Miss  Henley.
Thank you, Jason. I appreciate it.
(looking at book over  her shoulder) Find out what it is, yet?
Well, it's either a 44 million year  old Strychtosaurus or that cow Mr.  Sorenson lost last winter.
The boy, still standing beside her, begins to look nervou Slowly, he lets his weight rest against Katherine's shoul She smiles good naturedly up at him.
Go eat your lunch, Jason.
The boy immediately stiffens and begins backing up, almos relieved.
Sure, Miss Henley. Thanks. See ya.
Katherine watches him leave, smiles again, and goes back the book.

head_text.subj: AROUND THE BACK OF THE BUILDING

text: On the abandoned back stairs, a couple of Mexican boys si smoking cigarettes. They whistle and kid with the four yo girls that pass them going up the steps.

Is the abandoned, decayed part of the building. The four  girls know they're not supposed to be here and that's pro half the fun. They run through the crumbling halls, giggl and hiding from one another. Their cries, the smack of th shoes, echo off off the peeling halls. One of them is Mary, running down a hall, banging a stick with another girl. At a corner Mary peels off from her fr runs down a new hall, turns a corner, And comes on Simon. He's still curled where we last saw h in the wall niche where some lockers used to be. The two  stare at one another. Finally,
Hi.
Hi.
What's your name?
Simon.
You don't look so good, Simon.
No, I don't.
I'm Mary.
Hello Mary.
Does Miss Henley know you're here?
No one does, Mary. Can we keep it  just our secret. For a little while?
Mary thinks.
Okay.
You can hear her friends coming closer.
I have to go.
It was nice meeting you, Mary.
Mary goes to leave, stops, turns back.
Are you hungry? I could bring  something.
That would be very nice.
Okay. Bye.
She smiles and runs down the hall. Simon grits his teeth, turns to the wall, and prepares himself for a long, long  day.

An old fifties two-level, Polynesian lamps and glitter st now faded and browinish with water stains. Gabriel, the y man with the sunglasses and leather jacket we last saw ki down the door at the flophouse, walks up the apartment's  stairs to the second level, knocks once, and opens the do
Hasn't been very well looked after lately. Either has the occupant. Sitting slumped in a kitchen chair, staring at floor, he peers through dully yellow eyes that barely see to register his visitor.
Gee Jerry, you look like shit.
The eyes lift to Gabriel, revealing a pale, bloodless fac eaten with dried sores.
Leave me alone, Gabriel.
Soon, pal. Soon.
Gabriel drops into the chair across from Jerry and pushes aside with distaste the maggot-ridden plates of food pile on the table. He reaches his hand out to Jerry.
Come here.
Go away.
(sing-song, like to a  baby) Come here...
Gabriel puts his hand under Jerry's chin and turns the fa side to side, examining the cracked, decaying skin and fi eyes.
Hmmm. Still a little life left in  you. Barely.
Fuck you.
Gabriel releases Jerry's chin and slouches down in the ch
There's something I want you to do  for me.
What a surprise.
Don't be that way.
I just want to... Why won't you let  me...
I will, I will. Promise.
A dark, intestinal looking amber fluid begins to pool out Jerry's pant leg.
You need some new clothes, son.
A tear wells in Jerry's decomposing face.
Aw come on, don't start. You know  how I hate that...
I'm so tired. I'm so goddamn tired.
Watch the profanity. -- Just one  more favor. Honest.
(deep sigh) What?
I want you to get something for me.  A few personal effects the cops ripped  off from the lovely Allenwood Arms  on Seventh Street. It'll be sitting  in their property room down on San  Julian.
I'm supposed to just go in there?  Like this?
Give you a bath, put on some decent  clothes, (beat) Maybe a very large brim hat, you'll  be fine. Just go in between five and  five-ten, it's a shift change and  nobody'll notice you.
How do you know?
(cocks an eye) C'mon. (tosses yellow ID  card onto table) This should be more or less up to  date.
Got a name this stuff is under?
John Doe.
Why doesn't that surprise me.
Gabriel gets up, pats Jerry on the head, and walks to the door.
I'll see you tonight. (flips him silver  dollar) Here's some bus fare.

The SLAM of a racquetball against the scarred white wall an indoor court. It ricochets off the ceiling, hits the b glass partition, and is SLAMMED again. Four players, incl Thomas, grunt and sweat across the hardwood floor. It's  brutal. Shoulders and knees bang off one another. One of the players falls back, yells to Thomas.
Cover me! Cover me!
Thomas dives into position to make the save, recovers, an yells to the player as he dashes to the next corner.
Pop it up!
The player SLAMS it brutally at Thomas, who misses misera
Thanks a lot.
Another player picks up the dead ball and puts his arm ar Thomas.

You're missing the point of the game,  Thomas. You must absolutely trust no  one. Form alliances, but break them.  Lure another to trust you, then betray  him! You play with too much honor.  Sink to the gutter. Use people. Lie  and double-cross them.
Player #2 tosses the ball to Thomas, who serves, and the  scuffling is back on. Shouts to one another. Promises of  support.
Come on Thomas, let's take out Sam  together!

Thomas and Player #2 team up on a third player, pressing hard. Suddenly Thomas breaks back, intercepts the ball, a drives against Player #2. The about-face is too abrupt fo him and Player #2 is eliminated in a double-cross. He smi proudly at Thomas.
Magnificent decadence.
Thomas and the three players congratulate each other on t evil and treachery in each other's strategies as they sho down.
The important thing, Tom, is seeing  the game for what it is.
A sickening, hopeless, giant sucking  hole of depravity.
Laughs.

As Thomas combs his hair and slips on his regimental  detective's suit 'n tie, the other three put on their bla pants, shirts, and stiff white Roman collars. They're pri Two of the priests hoist their gym bags and head for the  door.
See ya guys next Tuesday, huh?
Thomas is left alone with Player (priest) #2, Bill.
So how's work?
Okay. Y'now.
Life on the dark side.
(beat) Can I ask you about something?
Sure.
It has to stay between us. I need  your word on it.
As a racquetball player or a priest?
I'll take the priest for the moment.
What's on your mind?
It's a case. We found this guy. He  was... different. But he had on him  an old bible.
He pulls the bible out of a cloth sack and hands it to Bi
It's a Vichini.
Worth a little?

More than a little. They're the best.  Sixth century. Hand illuminated.  Vichini only did twenty, each pocket  size for a king to carry into battle  beside his heart. Some consider them  the finest bibles ever made. I thought  they'd all be in museums. What are  you doing with it?
This one's a bit special.
How?
It's has a bonus chapter to St, John's  Revelations.
Really? What does it say?

(reading from slip of  paper) "And as in the first war, the angels  so fought over the nature of their  God, and there was much vanity and  destruction in heaven. For some angels  called their Lord the son of God,  and others called Him the begotten  father of Jesus Christ." What do you  think?

I've never heard that quote before.  Theologically, The "first war"  obviously refers to the war in heaven  where Michael the archangel threw  out Satan and his gang. Old time  bible stuff. But this implies there  was a second war. That's news to me.
And the rest of it?

Oh, it's a fairly common theological  debate. Or was. The idea that if  Christ is God's son, does that make  him less than God or are they the  same being in different forms. That  very argument almost tore the early  Christian church apart in the 4th  Century. That was the good old days  when people actually worried about  theology. Anyway, it was settled  when the bishops of the world got to  together at the Council of Nicene in  325 and hashed out the various  interpretations of scripture into a  uniform dogma of belief. The result  was the Nicene Creed, which basically  said that Christ was in fact the  same as God and was owed the same  power and respect as the Father.  That they were the same. (smiles) But it's not exactly the sort of  thing angels would fight over.
Why?
Well, they could just ask God, right?
Do you think it's possible that John  might have written that extra chapter?

Who knows? Vichini was the greatest  biblical scholar of the age, some  claimed he made his own translations  from the original writings. Maybe he  did find some unknown writings by  John. It's possible I suppose. John  always was a little negative about  angels. All this actually has  something to do with an LAPD murder?
I don't know yet. Maybe. Probably  not.
I hate to break it you, but that  particular family spat has been  settled for 1,600 years. Nobody loses  sleep over it anymore. Honest.
What did John have against angels?

Oh, he didn't trust them much. All  that running around smiting and  killing in the name of the Lord.  God's wild bunch. He thought it made  them fickle and vain. One click above  ghosts. Satan didn't help the image  much either.
Satan?
Well, he did start as an angel.
Thomas walks Bill out to his car.
So when are you going to get a real  job?
You mean with the Church?
You almost did it once. I never saw  a seminary student more called to  the collar than you. Why didn't you  ever become ordained?
It's a long story.
You'll have to tell it to me sometime.
Sometime.

The building is squat and brick. A non-descrip warehouse  that subs as a police evidence storage area. The sun is hard today as it beats down on Jerry's large- brimmed felt hat. Daylight and Jerry don't get along very well. His sunken, filmy eyes squint at its glare. The dec flesh cracking along his cheeks flames at its touch. He  shuffles down the sidewalk, the brackish, amber fluid tha gurgles down his leg filling his shoes and leaving behind shiny wet footprints like a snail. There's nobody around the back door and its unlocked. Jer shrunken claws pull it open.

Is a crush of filing cabinets and erector-set shelves. Al of it crammed with low grade stuff. The heroin busts and  million dollar currency arrests don't end up here. Here i all shoe boxes and dusty files. Fragments of small lives  forgotten. Jerry pulls the brim of his hat down even further as he w his way past rack after rack. The single uniform he meets looks only casually at Jerry's lapel ID badge. It's on th third shelf he finds it. John Doe #78. Jerry lifts the bo and walks out.
Gabriel steps off the elevator and follows the signs for  MEDICAL EXAMINER. Along the way he passes a checkpoint gu
Need a pass, friend.
I'll just be a second.
C'mon...
Sorry.
Gabriel walks back to the guard, smiles, and KNOCKS him c out of his chair with the back of his arm. The guard SMAC against the wall and crumples out of view.

Tiled floor and refrigerated corpses. Nobody's around whe Gabriel enters. He walks over to a file cabinet and remov a thick folder. Then he walks to the big filing cabinets, the ones that hold a body in each drawer. He strolls alon tapping each label till he finds the one he's looking for slides it open, and looks down at the naked body of the  gargoyle. He's been sewed back together. Kind of. Gabriel grabs the eyeless corpse under the armpits and drags him out onto t floor where he pushes the legs together and outstretches arms, like a crucifix. From his coat Gabriel takes out a  small vial of oil and rubs it onto the gargoyle's feet an hands. Anointing them. Then with the tip of his finger, h draws a faint sign of the cross on the forehead, stands, walks for the door. In the background, as Gabriel leaves, we see the body of gargoyle BURST into flame.
Katherine's students are shuffling back from lunch to the seats, making small talk and paper airplanes. Katherine d a head count, then stops a young boy coming through the d
Brian, have you seen Mary?
I think she's out back somewhere.
(to girl) Allison?
We haven't seen her since lunch.
We're you guys up in the...
The girls, Mary's friends, shrug innocently. Katherine si
Okay everybody, get started on today's  reading. Quietly. I'll be right back.
Katherine closes the door behind her. The class immediate erupts into goofing off. The door opens again.
I mean quiet.

head_text.subj: IN THE ABANDONED PART OF THE BUILDING

text: Katherine walks through decayed and rusting halls.
(calls out) Mary...
It's spooky up here. A part of the building Katherine cle dislikes.
Mary... (to herself) Shit.
Katherine calls out Mary's name a few more times, turns a few more corners, and suddenly comes on her.
Mary?
Mary's sitting beside Simon, the bleeding, ashen-faced ma with sunglasses. She's giving Simon a piece of sandwich a a coke. Katherine is instantly wary.
Mary, come here.
But Simon and I were --
Come here.
Mary reluctantly walks over to Katherine.
Go back to class.
But --
Go.
Mary frowns, waves once to Simon, and leaves. There's a  heaviness to the air around Simon. A kind of buzzing.  Katherine blinks her eyes a few times. Focuses.
She wasn't doing any harm.
It's not her I'm worried about.
Of course.
What are you doing here?
Small job. Mostly done now. Just  passing through.
This is school property, you can't  sleep here.
It wasn't part of the plan. Honest.
(notices blood stains) Are you all right?
No. Not really.
That buzz. Katherine rubs the side of her temple.
I'll have to call the police.
I wish you wouldn't, but I understand.
They'll help you.
Oh, I rather doubt that.
Katherine turns and leaves, her footsteps fading. Mary ap again.
Hi.
Hello. I thought you'd left.
I hid. I'm very clever.
I'm sure you are. (beat) You were nice to give me the food.
I know.
I haven't much time, Mary. And since  you've been so nice to me, there's  something I'd very much like to give  to you.
What?
Just for a little while. Something  very special. Can you keep it a  secret? The biggest secret ever?
Yes. What is it?
Come here, Mary.
She takes a couple of shy steps toward him.
Closer...
As she does --

Katherine, outside the building, rounding up some of the  kids who decided to take an impromptu recess. Hustling th last one up the stairs, she pauses suddenly. She hears  something. Faint coughing. Katherine walks back around the side of the building and  sees Mary bent over, vomiting. Katherine rushes up to her
I don't feel good...
What's the matter, pumpkin? Did you  eat something? (concerned beat) Did he give you something?
Mary coughs up the last of her lunch.
Can I go home now?
Katherine wipes off Mary's mouth with a hanky.
Sure, hon. Let's go.
Katherine drives Mary home, a dusty, tired mobile home sl among the saguaro and tumbleweed on the edge of town.

Mary and Katherine pull open the door and enter. Mary's  elderly grandmother is sitting watching "All My Children" She smiles at Katherine and looks at Mary with concern as the little girl rubs her stomach and explains something i Navaho.
Katherine helps tuck Mary in bed as her grandmother bring glass of water.
I'll have the school send over a  doctor.
The grandmother sits beside Mary, whispers gently in Nava and softly stokes her brow.
(on the phone) ...He's was just laying up there. I  thought, with the kids and  everything...
Most of my boys are up the highway  on a tanker spill at the moment.  They may be a while. These people  are rarely any problem. I'll have a  deputy come by tonight or tomorrow  and shoo him out.
He looked hurt.
They all do, ma'am. Inside or out,  they're all damaged goods.
Alone and tucked into bed, Mary stares off at something v very far away.
The sun orange and fading outside his window, Thomas drif off into a nap on his couch. The phone rings.
Yeah.
It's your friendly coroner.
Why is my friendly coroner, after a  long day at work, calling me at home?
I have something you'll want to see.
I doubt it.
No, you'll definitely want to see  this.
On the floor is the smoldering, blackened outline of a bo A thick, slimy goo gurgles and pops. The whole room is af with acrid smoke.
They also took the autopsy file.
"They"?
He, she, it. They took it. They also  lifted all the physical evidence  from the San Julian impound.
Where was everyone?
The cop at the desk is in the hospital  as we speak with a broken collarbone.  Everyone else was down the hall  watching the basketball playoffs.
Who won?
Temple.
Lucky.
Yeah. Foul on the buzzer.
Thomas jams his hands in his pockets and leans against an autopsy table. Watches the smoke curl slowly up from the  impossibly melted goo in front of him.
Looks like the snow angels we used  to make as kids. Lie down in a clean  bank. Move your arms up and down...
You know what this means. Our friend's  cleaned out all the evidence on this  guy. Everything.
Did the cop get a look at who nailed  him?
Tall. Smiled a lot.
Anything else?
He wore sunglasses.
Thomas pulls out out his notebook.
You gonna figure this one out, Tom?
I'm going to try.
When you do, give me a call. Tell me  I'm not crazy.
Gabriel crouches on the linoleum and pours everything out the evidence box onto the floor. He sifts through it, a s appearing when comes across the Chimney Rock Republican a its circled obituary.
You like the desert, Jerry?
Jerry is looking worse by the day. A rotting, oozing fiss has opened on his forehead. His right eye doesn't move  anymore. He sits on a kitchen chair glumly.
You promised. You promised that --
-- Soon. Honest. Don't be a pest  about it.
(sighs) Never trust a fucking angel.
Excellent advice.

Thomas sits hunched over his notes from the first day of investigation. Written in it is the Chimney Rock Republic and the obituary name of General Arnold Hawthorn. Lt. Pau sits down in the chair opposite.
Do you ever have one of those  afternoons where you feel no one's  giving you a straight answer about  anything?
Oh, maybe five or six times a week.
(reading sheet) It says here somebody got into the  property warehouse and cleaned  everything out of your evidence box.  No, he did leave one thing. A  footprint. 11-D.
Mud on his shoes?
Spinal fluid.
Thomas slowly closes his notebook.
I'm not going to get a straight answer  out of you either, am I?
Not yet.
The Lt. rubs his eyes tiredly.
I need to go to Arizona.
For your health?
So I can give you a straight answer.
Sure, why not? Take the kids. See  the Grand Canyon. Send me a fucking  postcard.
Sorry.
I've got a headache, Tom, and I hate  my life. If you have to go, go.
On an utterly lonely blacktop, Gabriel shoots by in his t down rambler, insignificant in the night's vastness. Jerr in the back, feet up on the seat.
Why do you need me? I can hardly  walk now.
Some things are human work, son.  Live or dead, human work. Besides, I  like you.
Lucky moi.

Gabriel suddenly stands on the brakes, SCREECHING the ram to a dusty stop. He kills the engine and everything is  instantly whispering night and coyote howls. Gabriel clim out and walks to the edge of a cliff. Far below, nestled  among the finger-like spires of volcanic cones, lies The  Town. Twinkling lights in a cold, dark embrace. Gabriel pushes his sunglasses up his nose and smiles.
I can always smell a graveyard.
Two coyotes begin fighting and snarling with each other i the dust nearby.

On a low hill at the edge of town. Cracked, sinking  headstones. The rambler's parked next to a new one, Slim  Pickens on the AM, as Jerry digs up the fresh grave marke General Arnold Hawthorne. Gabriel sits perched on the  headstone over the grave like a winged creature.
I hope you're enjoying this.
I always enjoy watching you work,  Jerry.
How did I ever get you in my life?
Come on, you didn't really want to  kill yourself.
But I did it, didn't I? I did kill  myself.
Well, yes. Technically.
And you're just keeping me alive.
Letting you die slower.
I'm so in your debt.
Thank you, Jerry. I'm touched. Really.

Jerry's shovel CLANKS onto something hard. He scrapes awa the dirt, revealing a coffin lid. With a socket wrench Je removes the fastening bolts, then with the edge of his sh pries open the lid. It's the ancient, wasted general we saw at the beginning. His medals flash in the moonlight.
Not much to look at.
Ah, but it's not what's on the outside  that matters --
Gabriel leaps off his perch down into the grave.
-- It's what's on the inside.
Gabriel reaches down, places one hand on the General's  forehead, one on his chin, and BREAKS the mouth open. He  gazes down into it. Then suddenly stiffens and straighten up.
(upset) It's not here.
Gabriel frantically look in the ears. Up the nose.
It's not here!
Oooh, bad news for the war effort.
(spins wildly on him) Shut up!!
Gabriel BANGS the coffin lid in frustration. Tries to thi
Now, if you were a soul, where would  you hide?
The hell away from you.
The numbers on the clock radio roll over five AM and the  news comes on. Thomas stirs in bed, rubs his eyes, and lo out at a sky untouched by any sign of dawn.
In coat and tie, Thomas sits in his spartan kitchen stirr a coffee when the phone rings.
Hey little brother.
(smiles) Hey. How's the world?
The world's the usual. Except for a  guppy. the world's minus one guppy  this morning.
And Jamie and Mac?
They keep asking for Uncle Tommy.  The only man that can make stuffed  bears talk.
My one true calling. What's up?
What do you mean?
It's five-thirty in the morning.
(beat) I just thought I should call.
You always were telepathic.
Don't go.
Thomas looks up at his overnight bag, sitting half-packed the dresser.
It's my job, Jan. I go places  sometimes.
I just had this terrible feeling  about it. What's happening, Tom?
I don't know.
I miss you. Even when you're here. I  miss you. I miss my brother. It's  been four years, Tom, since...
I know.
We're the only blood family we have  left, you and me. I worry about you.
I'll be okay.
Sorry about the dawn-attack call. I  love you.
I love you too, Jan.
He cradles the phone, stares at it, then picks up his  overnight bag.
Silent and dead at this hour. Gabriel's boots creak on th floorboards of the 19th century plank sidewalks. He taps finger aimlessly along plate glass shop windows.
Boy, what a dump, huh?

Jerry, limping on a foot that's caving in on itself, wipi the spinal fluid out of his dead eye, shuffles along behi Gabriel pops off the elevated sidewalk, grabs a parking m and swings himself playfully around.
Why can't this shit ever go down in  Miami? Or Bora Bora? I feel like  I've spent my whole damn stay in gin  swills like this.
Life's a bitch.
Gabriel suddenly freezes. He sticks his nose up, sniffs l a coyote, then abruptly drops to the ground in a push-up smells the dirt. Tastes it with his tongue. Smiles.
Well well...

A fracture of broken moon tumbles through shattered windo and falls dully across shapes old, shapes forgotten, and shape trying hopelessly to drag itself across the floor.  It's Simon; breath a rasp, blood-soaked pants leaving a l smear behind him like a hemorrhaging snail. He coughs, dr an arm across the lenses of his sunglasses, And looks up at a pair of black, lizard-skin boots.
Hi, Simon.
Simon rolls on his back and sighs.
Gabriel.
Simon looks up at puss-faced Jerry, leaning quietly in a  dark corner.
Don't mind me. Just along for the  ride.
Gabriel sits down against the wall.
So, what shall we talk about?  Theology?
I'm a little talked out on theology.
Fair enough...
Gabriel turns his boot to the moon, watches the pale ligh glint back off the lizard scales.
You know why I'm here.
Oh yes.
Don't happen to have it on you by  chance?
No.
That would have been too easy.
Simon suddenly JUMPS to his feet. Tries to escape. Jerry  trips him, SPRAWLING Simon back to the floor.
Please, Simon. Get serious.
Gabriel walks over to him. Puts his face close.
Now. Where's the soul? (beat) You know. So high. Used to reside in  the recently departed General  Hawthorne.
Simon doesn't answer. Gabriel shrugs.
Have it your way, big guy.
I do have one question.
Shoot.
Do you even remember what this war's  about?
Gabriel pauses, almost thoughtfully. Then he smiles.
That's hardly the point, is it?
I guess I never did get the point.
Happens.
How do you do it, Gabriel? How do  you go on and on in this place?
I like it here, Simon. I always have.
I'm so tired...
Gabriel grasps Simon's hand.
Then join us, Simon. Reject the Nicene  Council. We were here first.
I can't do it, Gabriel. I don't even  know why anymore, but I can't.
You know the routine.
(swallows hard) Yes.
Gabriel's hand is suddenly on Simon's face, fingers sprea claw-like. They press into the flesh. Hard. And harder. U Simon starts to bleed. Then to burn.
Katherine startles abruptly in her bed at the faraway sou of Simon's screams. Screams carried either on the wind or her dreams.
Asleep, sweaty, shivering, Mary suddenly opens her eyes.

Gabriel releases his grip on Simon, letting him fall back against the wall, afire. His clothes twist and blacken. H skin creeps and pops. His sunglasses melt and fall away;  revealing two hollow pits beneath. Gabriel lifts Simon's  entire body up off the floor by just the disintegrating f and stares into the hollow pits.
Not yet.
And the fires go out. Gabriel drops the crackling, acrid  body onto the floor. Impossibly, through the sizzling muc and molten hair, it breathes. It gasps in pain. It won't  die.
I can do this for five months,  Simon...
The skies above lighten and smear blue and red.
Finishes dressing for school, picks up her teaching bag, crunches out across the gravel to her pick-up.
Gabriel's lizard boots pace back and forth past Simon's  writhing, burning body. Gabriel's more jittery now. Losin his patience. He bends down and pulls Simon's face up to  his.
This is getting boring, Simon.
Amen.
Where is it? Where did you put it?
The seared skin around Simon's mouth comes off in Gabriel hand. But Simon is still, even now, silent.
Where is it!
He flings Simon with a horrible crunch against the wall.
I'm just about out of tricks here.  You're a tough one, friend. Old  school.
He walks over and places a hand with something like frien on Simon's charred shoulder.
God loves you, Simon.

And with the other hand Gabriel JAMS his fist into Simon' chest, PULLING OUT a lumpy, burned heart. Simon's mouth  springs open and hisses emptily. Gabriel slips the heart  into his pocket and lets go of Simon's shoulder. The body instantly disintegrates and crashes to the floor.
Katherine squints at the morning glare as she drives thro town. Pulling into the school's drive she sees, parked at the building's back door, a sheriff's patrol car.

Katherine comes up the stairs of the building's abandoned floor, passing the stacks of rotting desks toward where s last saw Simon. There's a bad smell in the air. At a turn stands a deputy that looks up as Katherine  approaches.
You may want to skip this, ma'am.

Katherine looks past him to where a second deputy crouche down beside... beside something. It's human shaped, but l a shadow. A shadow twisted in agony and slicked with a ta smoldering ooze. The smell is overpowering. The crouched  deputy has a handkerchief over his mouth.
God damn...
(to Katherine) Were any of your students up here?
Mary...
Katherine pulls-up and parks.

Mary is still in bed, droopy-eyed and sweating. Her  grandmother is there, and so is an elderly Navaho. He sta beside Mary's side, holding above her body a clenched pou that he passes slowly back and forth.
(to grandmother) How is she?
Same.
Did the doctor come by?

He found nothing. But something is  in her. I know. Something the  Belagaana doctor can't see. The night  people have been around two days  now. It is a warning. (nods to Navaho man) So we have called the hand trembler.  To find if she must have an Enemy  Ghost Way.
The old man mumbles a soft chant as he moves the pouch ba and forth across Mary's body.

Katherine walks back out toward her pickup. She stops. Th yards away, almost invisible in the sage say for the glar of its evil, intelligent eyes, is a coyote. As she feels  it's gaze a shadow suddenly crosses her shoulder. Katheri turns quickly but only barely catches, out of the corner her eye, a glimpse of something very large. And winged.
A huge semi ROARING deafeningly past on an empty desert  highway, KICKING UP a dusty cyclone that drifts over a on horse gas station and Thomas, sitting there in his car  checking a map.
Small townish; old adobe and stucco walls, cannon on the  front lawn, every door loudly declaring itself a departme SOCIAL SERVICES, COURTS, and, SHERIFF.

The Sheriff's personal office is turn of the century rega with high beam ceilings and rotating fans. Nothing seems  newer than 1940, including the coffee pot the Sheriff pou a mugful from. Trim with glasses, bolo tie and boots, he  looks like Barry Goldwater.
And to what do I owe the thrill of a  visit from a So Cal homicide cop?
He hands the coffee to Thomas, sitting in a chair beside solid oak desk.
Run of of the mill psycho killer  body dismemberment on our end. The  usual.
Lovely place, Los Angeles.
Got a lead I wanted to run down  Chimney Rock way. Thought I'd do the  courtesy of telling you first.
Big of you.
You're welcome to put a babysitter  on me if you like.
The Sheriff smiles.

Son, this is the third biggest county  in the country, not even counting  the 25,000 square mile Indian  reservation right next door, and  I've got fewer men than just one of  your little palm tree precincts to  cover all of it. 'Fraid the only  help you're gonna get from me, short  of another shoot out at the OK Corral,  is that cup of coffee in your hand.  A middle-aged secretary enters with  a stack of paper.
Here's the last week's watch reports.
She hands them to the Sheriff, who passes them on to Thom He flips through the stack, comes up with nothing. The  secretary hands another, single sheet to the Sheriff.
Bobby just called this in from Chimney  Rock.
Thomas perks at The Town's name.
(to Thomas) Sent a car up there this morning.  Teacher complained some vagrant was  sleeping in her schoolhouse.
The Sheriff's brow crinkles in consternation as he reads  further.
(to secretary) Damn it, get Bobby on the phone,  Clarice. What the hell is this suppose  to be?
(re report) May I?
The Sheriff hands it to him. Glancing at it we pick up wo like BURNED, BLACK SLICK, BODY OUTLINE. Thomas copies the name of the school down, gulps his coffee, and shakes the Sheriff's hand.
Thanks for the coffee.

(as Thomas turns to  leave) Small piece of advice, Lt. Dagget,  that I give free of charge to all  visiting big city policemen: It's  wild country up there. Always has  been, always will be. You come across  anything that snarls, you call me  first, hear?
I never turn down advice, Sheriff.  Especially when it's free.
Thomas's sedan passing through the vast, empty land.
A small clump of buildings emerge clinging hopelessly to earth. The Town.
A former miner's hotel, stone walls and sagging wrought i

Thomas tosses his bag onto the bed, opens the balcony doo and looks out on the crumbly shale hills, the abandoned  prospecting shacks, and the Chuska Mountains, clouds brew darkly across its shattered back.

A close-up of the circled newspaper obituary for General  Hawthorne. The paper lowers and reveals behind it the  general's grave. The dirt around the tomb is loose, recen filled. The grave keeper, a young, gangly, drifter type s nearby with his shovel.
How long ago was he buried?
Which time?
What do you mean?
Somebody dug him up last night. I  just finished putting him back.
Did they take anything?
Nothin' on the outside.

Thomas's breath escapes in warm clouds here in the unheat abandoned part of the building. Rats scurry away from fee on the dark, human-like stain on the floor as Thomas crou down beside it. He probes the dried, black, crusty flotsa with his ball-point pen. Just like the burned body back a the morgue. Far away you can hear the sounds of children. Of a teache voice.

It's only past the final door, into the smallest corner o the building, that the walls become clean and brightly pa by eager third graders. The creepy silence transforms its into the giggles of children as they bang open the classr door and whoop themselves outside for recess. The last one out is Katherine. She's surprised to see Tho
Hello.
(suspicious) Can I help you with something?
Tom Dagget. I'm with the police.
About the guy upstairs?
I'd like to ask you a few questions.
I've kinda got my hands full right  now.
I'll just tag along.
Katherine unlocks a hall cabinet and pulls out a stack of volleyballs. She tosses two to Thomas.
Here, make yourself useful.
Arms full, she pushes the building door open with her sho and backs out into the sunshine. She tosses the balls out the kids.
Okay, everbody stays on the courts  today. (kids groan) -- I mean it.
She sits down beside Thomas on the building's stone steps
What grade is this?
All of 'em.
Town doesn't look that small.
Nearly all ghosts now. When the copper  mine closed it took most of the town  with it. We just teach out of this  one corner of the schoolhouse now.  Rest of it's been abandoned for years.
You're the only teacher.
Yup. Just me. (to kid threatening  another) -- Randy...
But he --
Do it again and I'll put your head  in the door and slam it. (to Thomas) Love and understanding are important  tools in education.
Clearly.
The children skitter back and forth playing.
The man upstairs, did you talk to  him?
I wanted to know what the hell he  was doing there.
What did he say?
That it wasn't part of the plan. He  looked hurt. Bloody. Like someone  had cut him. That happens here. (beat) Was that... stuff... on the floor  really him?
Did any of the children talk to him?
Yes.
Who?
(protective) She's home sick from school today.
Can I speak with her parents?
They're dead. She lives with her  grandmother. I'll have to ask her.
All right. (stands, hands her  slip of paper) This is my number at the hotel.
Thomas starts away. Pauses.
Did you know Arnold Hawthorne?
The General? Saw him here and there.  It's a small town.
Military man?
About a million years ago. His  interests lately were more like  gardening and herbal tea.
Did you go to the funeral?
Everyone did. He lived here.
No dark hidden secrets?
There are no secrets in small towns,  Mr. Dagget, dark or otherwise.

Up the crumbly embankment, sitting perched on the roof of abandoned house, is Gabriel. He watches Thomas walk to hi car. He watches the children playing, lifting his nose to snort the air, like a coyote.

Thomas sifts through some clippings on General Hawthrone. Tactical genius. The man who saved Korea. Brutal. Almost  court marshalled a dozen times for his inspired savagery. truly ruthless man -- who spent the last twenty years qui tending his garden in a dying town.
Small, simple, and woodplanked. The church we saw at the  beginning. Thomas sits there, staring at the candles, the altar, the crucifix. He's alone there. But for a creeping buzz. A feeling in t air.
It's unusual to see someone of your  age in church on a weekday.
Thomas turns in surprise. Gabriel is kneeling in the row  behind, inches from his ear.
Don't get me wrong. I think it's an  excellent sign of character.

There's something cold and creepy about Gabriel. Out of p in here. There's another sound. Teeth chattering far in t back. Thomas turns and sees Jerry, deep in the shadows of the choir box. Jerry waves.
Never mind him. He shouldn't even be  in here. Least not standing.
Those sunglasses. Impenetrably dark. Like at the skid row flophouse.
You're not from here.
Either are you.
I'm looking for something.
Have you found it?
I will. Have you found what you're  looking for?
I will.
(appraising him) I don't doubt it. (stands) You'll let me know? When you find  it?
Where are you staying?
I'm around.
And he walks out, leaving Thomas alone in a place gone  suddenly cold.
There's a note waiting for him at the front desk: "Her na is Mary Tsosie. You can talk to her at noon tomorrow. I'l be at the VFW hall tonight -- Katherine."
Thomas sticks his head in through the door.

It's an Indian bingo game. Thomas' eyes drift down the ta packed with elderly faces and find Katherine and John the Navaho bus driver. Katherine waves him over. Both her and John are totally obsessed with the game, keeping track of several cards.
I got your note.
Have a seat. You need a card. Here,  play one of mine.
No, it's okay. Really --
You must learn to shed your high- strung ways, pale face. You must  learn the spirit joy in patience,  peace, and making fifty or sixty  bucks.
John, this is Mr. Dagget. Says he's  with the police, though judging by  his coat and basic command of the  english language, I don't think it's  from anywhere around here.
(shakes John's hand) Tom. From Los Angeles.
That near Oxnard?
Sort of.
Long way from home, Tom-from-Los- Angeles.
Thomas lazily glances at his card, his eyes opening sudde wide.
-- Hey, wait. I won. I won!
-- What? No way --
Recount! Recount!

A Navaho social in full swing -- square dancing. The Indi band on stage plays deeply traditional, inspiring, -- Han Williams. John easily whirls Katherine around; a steely-e master square dancer. Thomas leans against the wall tuggi on a beer. When John releases her for another partner she points at Thomas.
Your turn.
Oh, no thanks.
C'mon, don't be a drip.
She leads him out onto the floor.
I'm not very good at this...
(as they dance) No, you're not, are you?
She smiles. Gets a smile out of him.
Let me lead.

Couples drift off the building's porch and into the stree to cool off, smoke, and take a few hits off paper bags. J leans against the brick wall, tugs liberally from his pap bag, and exchanges war hoops with some friends across the street. He passes the bag to Katherine and Thomas.
So how's our star pupil feeling today?
Mary? The school doctor came by.  Declared it "Non-specific  gastrointestinal disorder".
Latin for "I don't have the slightest  fucking idea".
Will she be able to talk with me?
That's up to her. (to John) Mary's grandmother called a hand  trembler.
Uh oh. Hocus pocus time.
Is that serious?

Depends what the hand trembler says.  People call them in when they think  a witch or a Yei is trying to sprinkle  corpse sickness in their hogan, or  if the Night People have been hanging  around too much. Night people screw  around a lot, but they're good at  warning of evil ghosts.
Who are the Night People?
They come as coyotes.

Thomas sits in the truck's bed as they Katherine drives  through town. John, on the near side of royally toasted, his boot stuck out the passenger window. Thomas looks up the night sky. At its blaze of stars.
Beautiful stars out here.
John drinks again from his bottle, rests his head on the  open window and looks out.
Too much fucking sky in the desert.  It pushes on you. (sighs) Sometimes I wonder if anyone in heaven  even knows this place is here...
Early American bachelor. John collapses onto the couch as Katherine heads for the kitchen.
Where do you keep the coffee in this  joint?
Above the stove.
She messes with the grounds and filter. Thomas paces the  room, looks over the pictures and a few weavings.
What happens if the hand trembler  says a ghost has been...
-- Messing with Mary? If you're smart  you say thank you very much and forget  about it. But if you're heavy  traditional, and Mary's people are  serious traditional, you have an  Enemy Ghost Way.
What's that?

Goddamn expensive. It's a Sing to  purify and drive off the corpse  sickness. Two days of dancing and  ceremony and feeding the whole damn  village. Not even to mention hiring  the yataallii, if you can even find  one these days. And you can bet they  don't come cheap. But every clan  does it a bit different. Especially  Mary's.
You know them?

The Bitter Sky Clan. Hard core  reservation. No lights, no running  water, no HBO. Their village is out  on the edge of Old Woman Butte.  Million miles from anything. Witch  country. Settled right there in the  Dead People Land where no one else  would, right on top of the old Anasazi  village. They're a dying clan. Just  the old ones now. All alone out there  in the middle of nothing. (drinks) They can keep it.
Do people really still believe in it  all? Ghosts, Sings, corpse sickness?

Depends, I guess. Sometimes you go  along because it's a village thing,  or you don't want to disappoint  grandma. But sometimes, when you're  alone out there, far from town, and  the wind kicks up and sneaks into  your hogan... I don't know.
John closes his eyes and drifts off. Thomas wanders into kitchen.
I think John's out for the evening.
Saturday night in Chimney Rock.
She hands him a mug of coffee.
So how does a person like you end up  teaching here?

When I was younger I used to believe  that no matter how much you mucked  around in your life, one day, if you  listened hard enough, a voice would  tell you what you were really cut  out to do. And when it didn't show  up on schedule I decided to go look  for it. And I looked in a lot of  places, believe me. I drove that  road out there so far that the end  became the beginning again. And it  was when I got here that I realized  there never was going to be a voice.  So I stopped looking and took the  first job they offered me. That make  any sense to you?
Oh, I know all about voices. Problem  is not all of them are very nice.
How did you end up a cop?
It was the evil of two lessers.
Are you always this cryptic?
No. When you get to know me I can be  down right evasive.
Katherine pulls up to drop Thomas off.
Thanks for the lift. Tomorrow at  noon? At the little girl's house?
First trailer on the highway past  town.
Thomas climbs out.
I must say, Mr. Dagget, that you  don't seem very like a police officer  to me.
That's what my bosses keep saying.
I meant it as a compliment.
So taken. Goodnight, Miss Henley.
Goodnight, Tom-from-Los-Angeles.

Thomas lying in his hotel bed, flinching through a dream- filled sleep. There's glimpses of shattered images: War. Death. And a s dark-haired girl. Thomas's eyes open and fix on the ceili Out his window, perched on the railing of his balcony, is something dark and winged.

The honey warmth of dawn heats the bluish, quiet streets The Town. Across shale hills and abandoned 19th century  miner's shacks, there echoes the faint, clear notes of a  trumpet. The bluesy notes drift over narrow dead-end stre junked cars, and the abandoned copper mine out past the e of town.

Deep in the tunneled rock, past the rusting conveyor belt Gabriel sits in a small cave blowing Miles Davis on his  trumpet. There's just the blanket he sits on and a single candle. Jerry comes around the corner.
Get any sleep? (Jerry only stares) -- Just kidding.

As Katherine climbs out of her pick-up she sees several o her students standing in a circle. Crouched in the center talking to them, is a man. Gabriel. Jerry stands nearby. Gabriel is showing a boy his trumpet. Demonstrating where put his fingers.
...There, and there. Now pucker your  lips... aim it that way, and just  blow a little bit, this is a special  trumpet.
The boy puffs lightly. The trumpet emits a piercing, clea note that SHATTERS a window high up in the abandoned part the building. The youngsters whoop and applaud.
Very good, Timmy. Very good. Here,  have a Junior Mint on me. Open up.
As Timmy opens his mouth we clearly see Gabriel looking d into it. Looking for something...
Who's next?
Katherine approaches the scene warily. The children all b for their turn. Gabriel selects Sandra, one of Mary's sec grade friends, and puts her on his knee.
And who are you?
Sandra.
She can barely get her fingers around the trumpet.
And did you see the man upstairs,  Sandra?
A little.
Did you talk to him?
No.
And who did, Sandra. Who talked to  the man?
Mary.
And where is Mary, Sandra?
She isn't here. She's sick.
You've got very pretty teeth, Sandra.  Here, let me see...
He gently pushes down her chin with his thumb, opens her  mouth, and gazes in. Katherine enters the circle.
What the hell do you think you're  doing?
Gabriel looks up, unperturbed, and smiles.
Just talking to the kids, Ma'am.
Get off his knee, Sandra. Everyone  else, go inside. Now.
The kids reluctantly shuffle off.
'Bye, Gabriel.
See ya, kids. Be sure to study your  math.
He has the same sunglasses as Simon. The same cold, creep air about him.
Who are you?
It's a long story.
Jerry suddenly snorts loudly, trying to retrieve a sticky red glop that starts running out of his nose.
Ignore him.
Everyone else does.
I don't know what the hell is going  on, but you both better get out of  here. Right now.
You're right...
He climbs to his feet and stands close to her.
...You have no idea what's going on.

He stands there a beat. That terrible coldness that swirl about him. The shriek of ghosts under his breath. Then he climbs into the rambler with Jerry and pulls away. Kather watches the car drive off, then yells over to the school  janitor.
Al! Keep an eye on the children for  me. I'll be right back. And call the  sheriff.
Sheriff? What the hell do I tell  him?
Just call.
Katherine gets into her pickup and starts the engine.
Katherine drives through the main drag and out past the f of town. As she passes the old copper mine she sees, park near the mine's tunnel entrance, Gabriel's rambler.
As Katherine pulls up, she's surprised to see Thomas clim out of his own car.
You weren't suppose to be here till  noon.
You're a little early yourself.
I wanted to check on her.
That makes two of us.

On the sandy lot that extends back from the trailer is a  wizened cottonwood tree. Katherine, Thomas, and Mary are  seated beneath its shade. Katherine is protective of the  little girl, running a hand maternally through her hair.
How are you feeling, pumpkin?
Better.
This is Mr. Dagget, Mary. He'd like  to ask you some questions. You don't  have to answer if you don't want to.
It's okay.
There's a dreamy, far-away look in Mary's eyes. It worrie Katherine.
Mary, when you talked to man up in  the building --
-- Simon.
Yes, Simon. What did Simon say?
(smiles) That's funny. "Simon says".
Right. Like the game.
I'm good at it. I'm very clever.
We'll have to play together sometime.
Simon even said so. He also asked if  I could keep a secret.
And what was that?
Something he gave me.
What, pumpkin?
Then it wouldn't be a secret.
You're a good friend not to tell,  Mary. But I'm a friend of Simon's  too. So if you ever want to tell,  you can to me. Okay?
It's a secret...
Mary lowers her head and shuts her eyes.
...But sometimes it hurts.
Thomas and Katherine exchange looks. Mary's pretty eyes r again as she calmly asks, in that cute little eight year voice:
Have you ever killed a chinaman?
No Mary, I haven't.
They don't bleed. Not the way you  and I do. Or maybe it was just the  cold...
Thomas looks to Katherine for an explanation, but she's a confused as him.

I've killed them, you know. Lots.  You could always tell when they were  coming. There'd be the trumpets first.  Every note flat. Then those songs...  After that they'd charge. Right down  through the snow. The guns would  freeze and it would be just knives...  It was so cold and there were so  many of them. But I was smarter than  they were. Even at Chosin, I was  smarter...
Mary's been explaining this in a girlish, show-'n-tell ki of way. Suddenly her face cracks as her voice chokes with sob.
It scares me, Miss Henley. I hate  it. Please, make it stop!
She buries herself into Katherine's arms, sobbing.
Make it stop!
(rocking her) It's okay... It's okay...
Mary suddenly pushes away and runs back toward the traile into the arms of her grandmother.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to --
It's all right, Miss Henley. We know  you love Mary...
What are we going to do?
She's going to have the Enemy Ghost  Way. We leave this afternoon.
The grandmother turns and walks back to the trailer.
Where will they do the ceremony?
In the home village. The Hand Trembler  must have found corpse sickness...
They're taking her away? Shouldn't  she see a doctor?
She's already seen a doctor. (then, under her breath) That son of a bitch...
Who?
Gabriel the children called him. The  little shit was hanging around my  kids this morning asking about Mary.  He and his buddy make a real pair.
Maybe it's time I checked out Mr.  Gabriel.
Katherine turns from trailer and looks at him.
I know where he parks his car.
Katherine and Thomas drive back down the road leading to  town.
Chinamen? Chosin? I've never heard  her talk like that before.
Chosin Reservoir was a Korean war  battle the Marines had against the  Chinese, supposedly the bloodiest  hand-to-hand fighting of the century.  Someone been teaching that to your  class?
Sure, right next to Jack 'N Jill.
Where would she have heard it?
Nobody I can think of. (beat) Maybe one.
Who?
General Hawthorne.
Did she know him?
He didn't like children.
You couldn't and tell a story like  that to one.
He pulls over to the side near the copper mine entrance. sign of the rambler.
It was there earlier.

Thomas drives up the dirt path to the mine's tunnel entra They climb out and stand near its mouth. In the dust is t rambler's tracks and several footprints leading into the  mine. Thomas steps up to the edge of the tunnel. It's a black,  yawning thing that swallows the sunlight whole for breakf
If I was smart I'd call the Sheriff  or somebody in town who knows this  place. Then again, there is one thing  worse than getting killed.
What?
Looking like an idiot if it's nothing.
He pops his trunk and takes out a flashlight.
I'll come along.
No, if someone has to fall a hundred  feet down a black pit, he should at  least be on official duty.
Thomas switches on the light and takes a tentative step  inside.
Then again, it is kind of spooky in  there. Here, you can hold the  flashlight.

The sun very quickly becomes a memory. And after the firs bend it isn't even that anymore. There's only the glow of the flashlight; glancing off the abrupt edges of tunneled rock. Here and there are the flotsam of a bankrupt indust dented ore carts lying on their side, rusted drill bits,  piles of support timbers. And all around them the sucking blackness of the earth.
It's cold...
They walk further down into the mine. The atmosphere beco close and creepy. Thomas has been following tracks left i the dusty floor that abruptly disappear. He stops and sig
Shit.

-- A BAT suddenly SHRIEKS out of the darkness, glancing o Thomas's shoulder and TANGLING in Katherine's hair. She  screams and spins around, loosing her footing and half fa into a yawning ore chute she hadn't seen beside her. Thom rushes over and pulls her out. She climbs shakily to her  feet.
You okay?
Yeah... Sorry.
Thomas takes a last pass at the mine shaft with his  flashlight.
Well, I've seen enough.
As he turns to leave the flashlight burns out.
Wonderful.
He bangs it once against his thigh before he notices for first time a dim, amber light coming from a space between the rocks.
What is that?
I don't know. Maybe a bum or  something.
But his gun's out at his side. Just in case. They follow light to the gap in the rock, gingerly stepping into

-- That could easily belong to a bum. It's Gabriel and Je digs. Just the moldy blanket, single oil lamp, piles of  twinkie wrappers, And something else. From outside the cave it's the same whine, the same blurr that drips off Gabriel like sweat. But once they step int the room, into the lair, it suddenly jumps in volume. Thi is where Gabriel sleeps, and it's thicker here, like hone on the walls. Thomas has difficulty focusing his eyes.
Do you feel it?
...Yes.
What is it?

But Thomas can't hear Katherine anymore, her voice has  disappeared beneath the whine. As it becomes too much he  leans his weight against the rock wall and shuts his eyes It's then they come. Flashes of images: Of screams and fi Of impossible vistas of emptiness and death. And shriekin overhead, shrieking everywhere; grotesque, winged creatur with no eyes. Some with faces we know; Gabriel, Simon, an the gargoyle. All these images are being jammed into both their minds by the cave. Thomas forces his eyes open but the scenes playing all ar him won't go away. Tears are running down Katherine's fac as she stands there locked in the same images. Thomas stu about the room as if drunk, the visions, incomprehendibly black visions of war and destruction on an alien plateau, eat his brain. He sinks to his knees and begins to cry.
Oh no... Oh God no...

Katherine's curled up on the floor like a child, weeping. The images are driving them mad. Thomas, fighting the ins pounding at him, crawls pathetically across the floor to oil lamp. His fingers grasp it spasmotically as he rises his knees and leans back.
No!

He HEAVES the lamp against the cave wall, where it EXPLOD the oil erupting into a swirling blaze that CONSUMES the  corner. The images break a second in the heat and light and sucki wind. Just long enough for Thomas to grab Katherine's arm and pull her out of the room.

Katherine and Thomas lie in the dust outside the mine's t entrance. Catching their breath. Trying to organize and r the short circuits in their brains. Thomas rolls on his s squints at the sun. Katherine's voice is faint and raspy.
What... What was that? Hell?
...No. The voices. They were screaming  and fighting over... theology. They  don't sweat much about that in hell.  But they do in... heaven.
He squeezes a handful of dirt in his hands.
The son of a bitch. He carries it  around with him like a photo album.  A big, greasy cloud wherever he goes.  They all do.
How can that be heaven? Jesus Christ.  How? I don't even believe in heaven.
The tears start rolling down her face. She looks up and s at the endless sky above them.
You dumb fucking assholes! How could  you have done that!

That extra chapter by St. John was  right. It's a war... Just like the  first one. Just like when the angel  Michael beat Lucifer and cast him  out. Only now they've turned on each  other... Turned on each other in a  civil war over theology.
He laughs hopelessly at the insanity of it all.
Oh sweet God, theology. (sighs) "God's wild bunch". (shouts) God's morons!
How do you know know so much about  that?
I just know. (shakes his head) Yes folks, the good news is that  there's life after death in heaven.  The bad news is that it's as screwed  up as here.
They were like us.
They are us. Aborted children. And  they need us. They need our corrupt,  dark souls for their fight. They  need...
...Mary.
Katherine climbs abruptly to her feet and walks for the c
What are you doing?

I don't know what this is. I don't  know what I believe. I don't know if  my sanity is lying back in that cave  flopping around waiting for me. But  I know one thing. Those... Those  things aren't taking her!
Katherine and Thomas drive along in silence. Finally,
In those... visions... did you ever  see... God?
No.
Me either.
Katherine and Thomas open the trailer door and enter  cautiously.
Mary?

Thomas looks out the window and notices for the first tim parked behind the trailer, Gabriel's rambler. He immediat pulls out his pistol, runs for the closed door at the end the hall and KICKS it in. The door FLIES open, revealing  Gabriel sitting on the bed beside Mary.
Get away from her.
His gun's leveled at Gabriel's head. The angel sits there impassively, then smiles.
You know. Son of a bitch, the priest  wanna-be actually figured it out.  That's a rare club, son. At least  down here.
Back away from the kid, man. Now.
