She won't feel anything, honest.  I'll have to tear her apart of course --  just the way it goes -- but it'll be  all right in the end. A good catholic  boy like you, Mr. Daggett, you should  be on my side.
Goddamn it --
You're gonna have to watch that  profanity.

Jerry suddenly LEAPS out from behind the door and TACKLES Thomas to the carpet. The gun skitters to one side as Jer SINKS his rotting teeth into Thomas's shoulder. Thomas cr out and SLAMS his fist against Jerry's head, knocking off ear. Gabriel turns back to Mary's frightened face and smiles a he runs a hand through her hair.
It'll only be a moment...

Katherine suddenly HAMMERS Gabriel across the side of the head with a chair, KNOCKING him to the floor. As he gets she HITS him again. Thomas manages to bring his leg up and KICKS Jerry hard  against the chest, forcing him off. Gabriel GRABS both of Katherine's legs and PULLS, CRASHIN her flat on her back. Thomas scrambles for his gun, grabs it, and as Jerry come at him again spins and FIRES twice. The slugs RIP into Je chest and knock him to his knees. As the putrid, curdled  juices pump lumpily out of him, Jerry looks up at Thomas smiles.
Thanks man, I appreciate it. You're  a sport.

Thomas FIRES a slug into his forehead. Jerry's brain wink out as he collapses to the floor, dead. Thomas's gun is abruptly WRENCHED from his hand onto the as Gabriel NAILS him with a thrown lamp, vaults the bed  between them, and grabs him by the collar, SLAMMING Thoma up against the wall. He looks down at Jerry's finally lif corpse, incensed at Thomas's handiwork.
You little pest, do you have any  idea how hard it is to get one of  those?
He THROWS Thomas down onto a table, SPLINTERING it. Kathe climbs shakily to her knees.
You son of a bitch, why? Why do this?

Because I'm an angel, you miserable  wretch! I kill first borns while  their mothers watch! I turn whole  cities into salt! I even, when I  feel like it, rip the souls from  little girls! And from now until  eternity, the only thing you'll be  able to count on in your pathetic  little existence is never knowing  why! (deep breath) I'm wasting my time here. (turns to Mary) C'mon petunia, let's get on with  it...

Gabriel walks over to the bed. The moment he gets close,  Mary lifts Thomas's pistol up from the sheets and SHOOTS twice, the impact KNOCKING him on his ass. Katherine rushes to Mary, scoops her up and runs for the  door. She pauses beside Thomas, still lying in the wrecka of the table.
Go. Go!

Katherine disappears through the bedroom doorway. Gabriel spins around and stands. Thomas leaps from a ragg crouch, HITTING Gabriel low with a body-block. It's like butting concrete. Gabriel picks up Thomas by the scruff of the neck and HEA him THROUGH the flimsy room paneling. Thomas CRASHES with mass of splinters into the kitchen. He stumbles backward  hopelessly as Gabriel peruses him through the trailer. He desperately throws pots, glasses, anything at Gabriel. Fi trapped, he scrambles up onto the dinner table, SCATTERIN salt and sugar bowls, and DIVES through the levored windo

Thomas, in a hail of shattered glass, smacks the red eart pulls himself up to his knees and tries to stumble and cr away as Gabriel BANGS open the trailer door and stomps do the stairs toward Katherine, her arms around Mary.
He eases his gait, measuring the distance to her.
There's just those sunglasses coming. Those endless pits black.
...Have Her!!
Katherine lifts Thomas's pistol and FIRES. Again. Again. slugs BANG off the corregated metal, SMASH a window, KICK some dust, And PUNCTURE the propane tank beneath the trailer.

The entire trailer EXPLODES in a fiery cloud of TWISTING  METAL. Katherine huddles Mary close to the ground as flaming chu WHACK everywhere. Gabriel is HAMMERED to the earth and disappears in the ro fire cloud. Thomas, further away, is KNOCKED head-over-he in the ruddy dust. The fire cloud dissipates quickly into the sky, leaving b scorched brush, and little else, crackling softly. Gabrie body looks blackened and still. Katherine rushes to Thoma who's pulled himself up to his knees, a ragged slice abov his eye bleeding badly. She helps him to his feet and ove to the pickup, where he sits down against the tire as  Katherine pulls out her first aid kit. Mary's there, stan with her shaken grandmother.
(re grandmother) Where...
She was coming up the street.
Is Gabriel dead?
Mary's knelt down beside Thomas.
They're not like you and me. You've  got to cut their hearts out. The  only thing God gave them.
A sheriff car ROARS up, the two deputies exiting warily.
What the hell happened here?
Katherine's wiping the blood out of Thomas's eye. Gasping from the shearing pain, he tosses an ID at the foot of th deputy.
LAPD.
(looks at it, hands  it to partner) That's a start. How about the rest  of it?
From somewhere back in town there's the growl of a volunt fire engine.
That man over there. He's wanted.  Murder. I'm taking him in. (grimaces) -- Shit...
The pain's unbareable. Katherine dabs his cut with  disinfectant.
I think you're going to the hospital  first.
-- No, I have to --
Again, the pain. The second deputy has walked over to Gabriel.
Is he alive?
He's alive.
Cuff him. We'll take him to the  hospital in our car.
-- No, you don't understand. You  have to let me have him --

The volunteer fire engine growls up through the weeds,  drowning out Thomas's words. Two firemen kneel down besid him with medical kits. The deputy has walked over to his partner and the two are dragging back between them a cuffed, comatose Gabriel.
(hoarse, faint) You'll never hold him.
Thomas tries to get up, but the pain and a hand from the  firemen keep him down. As the deputies pass, he manages t desperately grab the one's pant cuff.
Take off his sunglasses... Jesus  Christ, just take off his  sunglasses...
Gabriel's head lies low between the shoulders. The deputy looks with concern at the firemen.
(re Thomas) He'll be all right. Just a bad hit.
The deputy nods. As they carry on to the car with Gabriel the angel turns his head slightly and smiles a smile only for Thomas.
(to partner) Let's get a splint.
The patrol car pulls away. As the firemen walk back to th engine, Thomas looks frantically at Katherine.
We have to get out of here.
But your head...
If you want Mary to stay alive past  sundown we have to leave, and we  have to do it now.

They lock eyes. Then Katherine without a word helps Thoma up into the passenger side of the pickup. Mary gathers he grandmother into the pickup's bed and climbs up beside he as Katherine starts the engine. The firemen turn in confu as the truck peels out of the lot and up onto the road.

Katherine's truck shoots by. Just before town, near the c mine, it slows down at a junction. And there, lying on its side down the embankment, is the  sheriff's patrol car. A single, bent tire turns aimlessly Katherine hits the gas and takes the junction that leads  away from town, out onto the endless expanse of the plate

The bandage on Thomas's forehead covers most of one eye. closes the other tightly, riding a spasm of pain, before  letting his forehead rest against the door glass and gazi out at the empty tracks of land.
Where are we going?
Mary's village.
Katherine looks over her shoulder to Mary's grandmother  sitting in the truck bed. She nods in understanding.
Katherine's pickup passing alone through the wrinkled des

A trading post with a few pumps, growing orange in the  weakening afternoon light. A scruffy dog barks constantly the teenage Indian sticks the nozzle in Katherine's picku Still glassy-eyed with throbbing pain, Thomas takes anoth handful of aspirin and climbs out of the cab. There's a tiny, weatherbeaten church across the weedy lot from the trading post with a pay phone bolted to it. Thom crunches across the lot, picks up the receiver, and punch in some numbers.
County Coroner's office, Assistant  Coroner Raphael speaking.
Willie?
Tom?
You weren't crazy, man.
And Thomas hangs up. He backs away from the phone and for the first time notices the church it's attached to.

Thomas steps inside. It's empty and there's some doubt wh it's been used in a generation. The pews are dusty and  scraped, some broken down completely. Thomas sits in one looks across the space and dust and years to the crucifix hanging behind the altar.
So what's the deal, huh?
The pew creaks and groans as he shifts his weight.
I mean, do you have any kind of plan  here? Cause I'm just about of ideas,  friend.
Jesus' pressed-metal eyes gaze only upward.

Do you even listen? Do you still  come to places like this? Old Man,  you have been calling me most of my  goddamn life, but every time I get  close, you just keep moving that far  away. What's it to be? You want me  to kill your henchmen? Can't you  even control your own killers anymore?
Thomas holds his face in his hands a silent moment. When raises we see the raw hurt in the eyes as he shouts,
What do you want from me!
The only reply is dust dancing in the light and the rumbl of semis on the highway. Standing in the back, watching Thomas with tears welling her eyes, is Katherine.

The road's turned to dirt and the plateau into a maze of  ragged cliffs and brutally hacked canyons. The light is shadowy and golden now as Katherine's pickup turns off the small dirt road onto an even smaller one th winds impossibly up the side of a volcanic butte. Higher and higher the truck climbs on the rutted and  treacherous path, till at last it crests the ridge and co upon

Perched frighteningly on the leading edge of Old Woman Bu this is the home of the Bitter Sky Clan. The village is a small grouping of ancient adobe walled hogans first built thousand years ago by the Anasazi. There's no electricity here, no TV antennas or frozen yogurt. Just the slow curl cooking fires drifting up through smoke holes and the ste deeply lined face of an old Navaho man approaching the pi as Katherine stops. The old man wears jeans, a bright maroon silk shirt, and black felt reservation hat with a turkey feather. He hold in his right hand a small leather case.
I am Bartholomew Grey Horse, born to  the Deer Spring Clan, born for the  Slow Talking People. Today I am the  yataalii for Mary Tsosie of the Bitter  Sky Clan.
The old man, Bartholomew Grey Horse, walks up to Mary and her grandmother sitting in the bed.
Ya-tah.
Ya-tah-hey.

Several villagers approach and greet Mary and her grandmo some nodding politely to Thomas and Katherine as they cli out of the cab. Nearly all of them are elderly. Thomas, one eye still half-shut by a bandage, walks over the village's edge where a short stone wall, and little e separates the adobe homes from the long, 2000 foot drop t the desert floor. He leans against it and gazes out on a  view that must encompass half the world. In all direction for tens upon tens of miles, there are only volcanic spir and crumbling buttes, all reduced from up here to short,  ominous playthings. A village truly alone in the world.
This is a good place.
She's appeared beside him. Thomas crouches down to her le and smiles.
Yes?
Mary's sight is on the view, eyeing it critically.
Separate water source. Stocked grain.  Only one possible approach. A man  could, with the proper defenses,  hold off an entire battalion for  weeks. Months.
Thomas's voice sighs sadly as he runs a hand softly throu her hair.
Which one of you is that talking,  Mary? Or do you even know anymore?
Mary's eyes fill with tears as her grandmother appears an leads her back to the adobe hogans. Grey Horse, the yataalii, is there now.
We will start the Sing soon to remove  the Yei spirit and stop the ghost  sickness.
This might not be the work of a Navaho  ghost.
It's all the same.

Night creeps over the Chuska Mountains across the crusty  caliche flats and over the village, pushing back the dyin day to a thin, fading blue line etched across the horizon As the darkness settles on the hogans we see a glimmer of light from within and the rising, guttural chants of the  yataalii.

Under the village, beneath the surface of the butte, is t large communal kiva room. Accessible by a single ladder  through a single smoke hole, it is down here that the vil performs its Enemy Ghost Way for Mary. The little girl is there, attended by her grandmother, si stoically still on a blanket as Grey Horse, grasping his  painted prayer sticks, by the glow of a fire chants the E Ghost Way cure. Katherine's eyes sting in the smokey air she watches Grey Horse take from his case small handfulls colored sand that he pours in fine patterns onto the floo The whole Bitter Sky Clan surrounds them. Old, lined face A small, dying people here to support its last granddaugh
Katherine stands there in the chilly darkness outside the kiva. Mary's grandmother, passing with some other women,  pauses and squeezes Katherine's arm.
Now we sleep, Katherine. Tomorrow,  after dark, we begin again.
The fire has died to embers, casting its weak glow on a n empty room.

Katherine wanders along the edge of the village, turning her collar under a blinding mass of stars. There's nothin beyond the village. Not a light, not a sound. Say the win It is the icy brush of wind on her body that now whispers
Hello, Katherine.

Like the wind, it is low and thin and hoarse. Like the wi it seems to come from everywhere. And, like the wind, it utterly without pity or remorse. Katherine turns. Perched on the wall behind her in a low crouch is a figur clad entirely in layers of black. Its head and hands are  hairless and waxy white. There are eyes in this winged he but blood chilling ones of putrid yellow. There are endle scars and shapes and wrinkles, but mostly, only, there ar the eyes. Katherine gulps down, with only partial success, the hyst rising in her throat.
Oh Lord, I can't do this. I can't do  this anymore...
We must talk, Katherine.
It's takes all her strength to look upon him.
You're... You're... (tries to form the  word) ...God?
God is love, Katherine.
The eyes narrow. Rippling pools of unfathomable evil.
-- I don't love you.
There's a crouched silhouette beside the figure. Dimmer.  Skinny. A wheezing sycophant. An afterthought. Katherine backs away from both of them.
I can't. I can't do this tonight. Go  away.
I can kill you, Katherine. I can lay  you out and fill your mouth with  your mother's feces. Or I can talk  with you.
Katherine stops. Faces him.
I am here, before you, in a form to  put you at ease.
Good job.
The sycophant shivers and ruffles something feathery unde its cloak.
I rarely do this in person. I am,  perhaps, somewhat out of touch.
Are you one of them?
No.
You're not an angel?

Oh, I am an angel. A very special  one. The first. The oldest. The naive  eagle scout, he once loved me above  all others, and I him. It was the  only true love for either of us, but  like all true love, it couldn't  possibly last.
The figure cranes his neck around to the horizon beyond t The movement makes a liquid, snapping sound.
The winged party boys will come,  Katherine. They'll come to feed on  the guts of your little Mary.
What do you care?
I have my interests...
He turns back to her.

The naive eagle scout, he has his  interests too. He even has a place  for them, as I do for mine. Big,  shiny place. You'd like it. Only  it's been empty for a long time.  Can't open till after the  resurrection. The problem's with the  hired help. Always had problems with  the hired help. They're arrogant,  boastful little pricks. Not like me.  What I did I did for love. But they,  the winged party boys, even before  the park could open for its first  customer, they started fighting over  the popcorn stand.
The figure shifts his perch on the wall.

You see, Katherine, heaven can't  start accepting guests till this  fight is settled. And without people,  there is no heaven. All those good  and true souls left mouldering in  the ground clutching their H-tickets  and waiting and waiting and waiting...  Some, lying down there with the worms  century after century, they start to  get doubts about the whole program.  That's when, out of sheer boredom,  some of them come to me. Because I'm  always open for business. 24 hours a  day, seven days a week. Even on  Christmas.
The figure's face darkens.

Some of the angels cheat. They sneak  a few souls in to help with the fight.  The really dark ones. And now one of  them has found a special soul so  wonderfully sick that it might just  win it for them. And if one side  wins, even the wrong one, then there's  no fight. And if there's no fight,  there can be a heaven.
And if there's a heaven?
I'd be very unhappy. (beat) I am here to help you and the little  bitch not because I love you, not  because I care about you, but because  I want this war to go on and on and  on.
The figure straightens up, stretching its spine.
I bring you the chance to save your  Mary, Katherine. And along the way,  stop the resurrection.
How?
Listen when I speak. Now go to bed,  Katherine. Tomorrow, I promise you,  is a big day.

Thomas's sitting on the hard-packed floor, leaning agains the adobe wall, maybe trying to sleep. Mostly trying to i the thumping pain in his head. The oil lamp's flame shudd in the gust of Katherine opening the door.
Is it over?
For now. They start again tomorrow.
And at the end of it?
The Enemy Way chant removes the  invading yei ghost.
Will it work on a general's soul?
We'll see. (beat) How's the head?
Still attached. Barely.
She sits down on the floor beside him.
Here, I'll change the bandage.
She carefully unwraps the blood-soaked gauze.
Does that hurt?
No.
Then I must be doing it wrong.
She peels back the compress and dabs the wound.
I saw the devil tonight.
How nice. Which one?
The main one. Satan. Lucifer. The  dark angel. You know.
What did he have to say?
That he did it all for love. That  and I have a choice. Mary's life or  a billion souls waiting in the  pipeline for heavenland to open.
You're not kidding, are you?
No sir.
Satan? You're sure?
You had to be there.
Thomas suddenly slams his fist against the wall in anger.
Why wasn't I!
We can double date next time if it's  that important to you.
You don't understand, I've spent my  whole life... (looks upward) I don't suppose it would occur to  anyone in authority to fill me in on  what's going on every once in awhile,  huh? Shit!
The ache in his head's flared up. He leans it back agains the wall to ease the pain.
Did he say anything about the Nicene  Council? About the rank of Jesus  Christ in the holy Trinity?
It didn't seem important to him.
Katherine finishes taping the new bandage.
Are you a priest?
A near miss.
Why?
It's a long story.
This may be your last chance to tell  it.
A wind outside rustles through the hogans.

The other night, you were talking  about waiting for a voice to call  you to something. Well, let me tell  you, the worst thing that can happen  to you is to be called to something.  Since I can remember a voice from  somewhere deep in the Church called  me. So loud and so often that by  thirteen I knew I was going to be a  priest. You know what that's like?  My parents, friends, all of them  thought I was crazy. But see, I had  this voice. The voice that kept  coaxing me along, telling me there  was a reason. So I entered the  seminary and was half way to my  starched white collar when my mother,  father, and my little brother were  wiped out in a car crash.
He pauses, the old emotions creeping back up on him.

I had never asked anything of the  voice. Not when the neighborhood  kids made fun of me, not when my  father looked down at me like some  knock-kneed faggot. I never questioned  a damn thing. But on the morning I  spent looking down at three parallel  graves, I asked it one question.  Why. Why were these people taken  from me? And the voice, that same  voice that would wrench me out of my  sleep some nights with its jabbering,  it was suddenly stone silent. It was  the only question I ever asked of it  and it just left me hanging in the  fucking wind...
He blinks back the tears welling in his eye.
So after that I traded in priest  school for homicide school. Because  if God wouldn't talk to me the devil  sure as hell would, and his ways  were a lot easier to understand.
We've never seen God, have we? Not  in any of this.
Yeah, He's certainly a shy son of a  bitch, I'll give Him that.
Maybe we're not supposed to. Maybe  that's faith.
Do you still have faith in anything,  Katherine?
I have faith in Mary. And that I'm  going to save that little girl from  those creeping things out there.  From all of them.
Maybe you were called to something  after all.
Maybe we both were.
The oil lamp wanes and fades. Katherine lays her head on  Thomas's shoulder, and as darkness swallows them he holds her. They hold each other.

John the bus driver lying fully dressed on his bed asleep The night breeze through the window, and maybe something  else, tickles his nose. His eyes open, blink, turn left,  right, then up, -- And see Gabriel perched on the headboard, staring down him.
Heavy sleeper, John.

John's eyes open wide in shock. Gabriel's skin is blacken and blistered in parts. Whole shards of his shirt are mis John tries to sit up but Gabriel forces his head back dow with his palm. With the ease of a spider he slides down a beside John.
Don't -- Don't hurt me, man. My  wallet's in the dresser.
Don't be such a materialist, John. (sees empty bourbon  bottle on dresser,  sighs) No end to your bad habits.
What do you want?
A moment of your time.
You ought to have that nose looked  at, man.
Gabriel leans said nose in very close and whispers,
Where are they, John? Katherine and  Mary? Where would they go?
What? Mary? I don't know.
Sure you do. Think hard.
No, really. I don't know. The school  maybe.
Now you're not even trying, John.  You're Katherine's best friend. She  tells you everything.
I'm just the driver, y'know?
Gabriel extends a blistered, open palm over John's face.
I can help you remember, John...

head_text.subj: FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROOM

text: We see Gabriel leaning over John as a sickly yellow glow  begins to rise and reflect off the walls. Beneath it come John's worst and deepest screams...
Gabriel SPLASHING the soot off his face and arms in a sma institutional bathroom. He looks at himself in the mirror runs a hand through his hair, and walks out the door into

At the end of it is the intensive care unit, that  institutional purgatory where a small handful of patients wired and tubed and oxygenated, lay inconclusively betwee life and death. There's a nurse's station there, all heal status video screens and a single nurse that looks up fro her work at Gabriel.
Can I help you?
Someone's going to die here soon.  I'll just be a minute.
There's no visitors allowed in ICU.
The timing's important. I can smell  these things, you know.
The nurse reaches for the telephone. Gabriel takes it awa from her with one hand and with the other grasps her face open-palmed and whispers,
Go to sleep.
The nurse slides out of her chair and collapses to the fl Gabriel pulls out the metal clipboards holding each patie chart and flips through them, tossing one after another a as unsuitable.
Recovering... Recovering... Stable... (finally settles on  one) Deteriorating critical.

Satisfied, he steps over to one of the beds, pulls back t curtain and sits down beside an unconscious, middle-aged  woman. He watches patiently, listening the beeping scrawl the EKG above her. It was weak to begin with but now it's faltering badly,  becoming the unsynched etchings of a child. A beeping ala has begun to ring and her breathing is slowing to nothing At the last possible moment Gabriel places his fingers ac her face, whispering to her, coaxing her.
Whoa, not just yet. Come on back.  That's it...
The EKG's still flat but the woman is breathing. She begi to choke, to cough, then suddenly sits up and opens her e She looks in disbelief around her, finally settling on  Gabriel's grin.
Hi.
A look of utter desolation and sadness sweeps over her as she begins to cry.
No, no...
Hey, c'mon, don't start... (looks at chart) -- Rachael. Here... (hands her kleenex) It's only for a short time. (grins) Promise.

The sun cresting the Lukachukais and warming with honey  colored reflection the interior of the hogan. Katherine's head is still on Thomas's shoulder, the two o them asleep sitting against the wall. Katherine opens her eyes and rises stiffly. She looks out the simple window to the glow of morning without expressi turns, and walks out.
Mary's Grandmother and some of the other elderly villager are attending Mary as Katherine enters. Mary is sitting u in her bed. She smiles at Katherine.
Hi, Miss Henley.
Hi, pumpkin. Good morning.

Grey Horse is kneeling near the bed preparing a bowl drin Into it he crushes charcoal, dodge weed, juniper and ghos plant. This he stirs, heats over flame, and feeds to Mary She grimaces and leans back in the bed as Grey Horse says brief prayer.
Katherine runs into Thomas outside the hogan.
How's the head?
Shitty. Coffee?
She accepts a mug, blowing a cloud of steam off the top.
What are we going to do if he comes?
You mean when, right?
When he comes.
There's no phone here? Radio? (she just looks at  him) Stupid question. (beat) If we were smart we'd leave. Get to  a town. A sheriff station.
Mary's ceremony isn't over yet. The  Enemy Ghost Way. The alien spirit  hasn't been driven out.
Do you really believe in the ceremony?
Would you have believed in any of  this three days ago?
(nods) So we stay and dump the General's  soul.
You have the gun?
With one shot left. The spares -- (sniffs his shirt) -- And a change of clothing, are all  still at the hotel. (sighs) We're going to have to come up with  something.
We could always ask him.

Thomas looks up. She's referring to Lucifer, who's appear perched on the edge of the low, eye-level hogan roof. The sycophant is also nearby, chattering its teeth and starin at Katherine with jealous, rabid eyes. Lucifer shivers, a claw turning up the collar of his cloa
I always forget how cold it gets in  the desert.
The swimming, bottomless eyes fall on Thomas.
Mr. Daggett, I presume. How's the  faith?
Thomas can't bring himself to say anything. To form the w
Come come, must you be so wishy-washy  about everything? With the absent- minded eagle scout, I can see that.  But you're looking at the devil man,  say something.
Fuck you.
Much better. Can I have some coffee?
Thomas gingerly hands him the cup. The angel Lucifer lift it, and with something unimaginably awful darting out of mouth, drinks. He offers the mug back to Thomas for a sip
Keep it.
He finishes it. Cranes his neck.

I have come to remind you that the  winged party boys are just that:  spoiled boys. You are armed, however  pathetically, with the one thing  they never really understood:  theology. It's not much, but that's  life.
Is this supposed to be our "win one  for The Ripper" speech?
Don't press your luck, Mr. Daggett.
And you know instantly, in the bottom of your stomach, th those eyes mean it.
Go and get ready, Thomas.
Thomas hesitates, holds the gaze, then turns and leaves. an instant Lucifer sweeps down from the hogan roof to  Katherine's side. Face and eyes and maggot breath  uncomfortably close, he smiles.

Have you ever considered Katherine,  that the great absentee landlord,  the soft-eyed eagle scout your  childhood prayers are for, is just  using you? That you're only the  exterminator to get rid of his pests?
Lucifer places a cloaked arm around her shoulder and lead her to the walled edge to look out across the endless pla His mouth presses against her ear and whispers,
God's junkies are coming, Katherine.  And when they do, all hell is going  to break loose...

A tiny speck on the empty horizon. It grows, takes shape, and finally becomes a red convertible rambler as it WOOSH past on a desolate throat of forgotten highway. Gabriel's at the wheel. Beside him, grey-blonde hair stre out behind her, is Rachael, recently lifted from the file and-forget section of the hospital ICU. She tilts her hea up. Lets the sun warm her pallor. Just a sociopathic ange and his somewhat deceased babe out for a top-down cruise  across a sixty million year old desert. It could happen.
A reality bruised waitress, Madge, sets down a coffee and milkshake before Gabriel. He downs the shake in one belt.
Say, Ma'am, any idea where I can  find Old Woman Butte?
It's on the reservation.
I don't suppose you could be just a  tad more specific. Madge.
The waitress' eyes move from the guy with sunglasses and  burn marks on his shirt to the woman sitting alone outsid in the rambler.
Isn't your friend hungry?
Not for a while, I'm afraid. Funniest  thing.
Madge has a lot of things she misses in her life, but one them she decides isn't Gabriel.
Take 522 to the Sonsela Wash cut- off. First dirt road go left. Twenty,  twenty-five miles you'll see it.  Big, black and all alone.
Gabriel downs the coffee, stands, and tosses a bill on th counter.
I doubt we'll meet again.
Suits me.
Thomas drags a heavy chain from Katherine's truck and beg fastening it to a post. Lucifer watches perched on a near rooftop.
You could always lend a hand.
Lucifer just smiles or sneers or whatever he does with th hideous mouth.
Grey Horse begins laying out his prayer instruments as Ma is prepared with paint and oils.
Katherine leans against the doorway, nervously watching t horizon.

The sky thinning into uneasy pastels as the sun falls  unceremoniously toward the mountains. A few lanterns have been lit, and from inside the kiva can be heard the chant of the Navaho Enemy Ghost Way. Katherine's eyes are still on a horizon dropping off into shadow. She stiffens. There, at the end of the earth, app a silent plume of dust. It could be anybody's car, but it can only be one car. Thomas steps up beside her.
He's coming.
Thomas sticks his head into the kiva, speaks softly to on of the elderly villagers attending the ceremony.
Is there any way to speed this up?
No.

A fire has been built on the kiva's floor. Through the ch smoke can be seen Mary lying on a mat as Grey Horse chant to the yei spirits and adds fine colored earth to the gro sand painting beside her. His voice rises and falls in  guttural syntax. He's coaxing. Coaxing the alien spirit o of the child.
Lock the door.
He pulls his head out and hands Katherine the pistol.
Stay inside. It's only one round, so  make it count.

There's a pause and for a moment their eyes lock. She tou his arm, almost says something, then disappears into the  kiva. Thomas closes the door behind her. He turns and loo out at the distant plume of dust. Growing closer.

Radio turned up, sophomoric grin glued on his face, Gabri roars past and begins the snaking climb up the side of th butte. The sun has almost completely slipped away now, le the land a deathly bluish grey. The road flattens out at the top of the butte and Gabriel can see the village glowing at the far end. He punches th rambler, winding it up for the last stretch, and pats the blonde on the knee.
You'll like this, Rachael.

Maybe not. There's a sudden glint of metal in the headlights as Thom at the last moment PULLS UP the heavy chain and HOOKS it  over the far post. Gabriel does something pointless with brakes and SLAMS forward into it. The whole rear of the c STANDS UP on impact, PITCHING Gabriel through the windshi into the dust. Thomas steps out from behind the post armed with an iron  bar. The rambler hisses and belches a death rattle as he  cautiously walks toward the spot of gloom where Gabriel l
(breathless) Nice move.
Thomas's feet crunch softly closer.

You ought to come work for us.  Upstairs. We sneak the odd civilian  in now and then, you know. You'd  like it. Nobody tells you when to go  to bed, can eat all the ice cream  you want. And you get to kill. All  day and all night. Just like an angel.
Thomas doesn't answer. Gabriel's body looks ravaged as he carefully steps closer and closer.
Save yourself, friend. Why go to the  wall with the bitch and her rug rat?  It'll all turn out the same anyway.  Here or in heaven, we're still gonna  tear the kid apart.

I'm not an angel, heaven or hell.  I'm a man you eyeless puke, which  means I have one thing you never  will. A soul. And though I may,  somewhere inside, believe in a God,  I will never, never, believe in you.
A little speechy today, aren't we? (sighs) Okay pal, have it your way.

Gabriel's legs suddenly SWING AROUND and SMACK Thomas,  sprawling him back into the dirt. The iron bar goes flyin as Gabriel in a flash is on top of him. Thomas thrashes b Gabriel easily pins his shoulders and sits on his chest.  Without hurry he uncurls the fingers of his right hand.
This is going to really, really hurt.
Thomas's eyes are wild with fear.
...You -- your war...
Gabriel's spread fingers lower themselves toward his face
C'mon, son, out with it. Make this  one count.
Your war's a lie!
(pauses) What?
Running around acting like this is  really about whether Christ is just  the son of God or if he is God.  Bullshit! That's not what this is  about at all, is it?
You're wrong.

Then prove it to me, Gabriel. I  studied three fucking years of  theology before I picked up a gun.  C'mon, you're chief goddamn angel,  I'm just a little man. Prove to me  Christ is just a son and less than  God. Prove it!
Gabriel hesitates.
I don't have to.
Because you can't! Because this war  isn't about some obscure medieval  hangup. You're just jealous.
You're wrong!
Try me, Gabriel. Go on. Prove to me  the temporal nature of the Trinity.  Show me through logic how the Son of  the Word can be separated from the  Father. Fight me with philosophy,  Gabriel!
No!
Because you and your army are wrong!  And you know it. You knew it sixteen  centuries ago.
We don't have to listen to him! He's  just a son!
That's it. You're jealous. Jealous  He could love something more than  you...
(hisses) Shut up...
Gabriel's becoming unglued.
If you wanted to know so badly,  Gabriel, why didn't you just ask  Him? Why didn't you just ask God?
A shudder passes through Gabriel. He straightens up and l down at Thomas as emotion racks his body.
Because He doesn't talk to us anymore!

The two stare at one another. Then Gabriel, lost in himse suddenly turns away from Thomas and walks into the darkne For the village. Thomas climbs quickly to his feet, spins around -- -- And is HIT full-force by a rabid, SHRIEKING Rachael. H legs lock around his body vise-like as her teeth and nail DIG into his skin. He cries out and stumbles to the groun The two grapple furiously in the dust, Rachel's crazed fa taking BITE after BITE out of his shoulder and neck. Thomas manages a fistfull of her hair and YANKS the fangs off his shoulder. With his other arm he CUFFS her hard,  BREAKING the grip and ROLLING her aside. He staggers to h knees and begins to run. Shrieking, a mad porcelain bansh out of the dusk, Rachael catches up and TACKLES him. On t way down his head strikes a small stone wall and the pain white thunder. Gagging and weeping in blank shock, he cra on his hands and knees as Rachael OPENS UP his arm from  shoulder to elbow with her nails. As the blood tumbles li ribbons, Rachael JUMPS onto his back, DIGGING her claws i his scalp. It's about all one human can take. Mad with pain and anger and desperation, Thomas manages t climb to a shaky crouch, Rachael still shrieking on his b Throwing all his weight backward, he JAMS her into the sh stone wall. The impact SNAPS her hold and PROPELS her ove the wall -- And two thousand feet down the side of the butte. Thomas Daggett can only curl up into a ball, gulping shal shuddering breaths.
Gabriel walks resolutely up to the first hogan and KICKS  down the plank wood door. No one home. He walks to the se and KICKS its door down. Nothing.

Mary's ceremony is nearing a crescendo. Grey Horse has do the colorful mask of the yei god Monster Slayer as the  relatives now join in the guttural chants of the Enemy Gh Way. Through the thick, choking smoke of the ceremonial f we see Katherine, nervously watching the door.

head_text.subj: IN THE DARKNESS OUTSIDE THE VILLAGE

text: Thomas tries hopelessly to make his way back. Stumbling e few steps, he's beyond pain and into driven numbness. It' hopeless though. We know it.
Gabriel KICKS down another door to another empty hogan.  There's only one left. As he approaches, from within can heard the muffled sound of chanting.
Takes a few more fumbling steps and falls again. He reach out to something metal for support. It's Katherine's pick
Steps up to the kiva door and KICKS it. The frame buckles but holds. He steps back a few feet, puts all his weight  into a turn, and KICKS again. The door SHATTERS.
Wood splinters ROCKET through the smoke as Gabriel appear in the doorway. Grey Horse, everyone, freezes.
Relax folks, it's just a soul.
From out of the smoke steps Katherine. She FIRES, one rou into Gabriel's side. The archangel is pitched against the kiva's wall, where he stays a moment before turning to  Katherine.
I'm getting real tired of you.
She stands her ground between him and the child.
Go to hell.
Heaven, darling. Heaven. At least  get the zip code right.
It's all the same, isn't it?
No. In heaven we believe in love.
And what do you love, Gabriel?
Once again, the shade of doubt holds him up. But it's qui pushed aside for a corrupted grin. He's given up all pret
-- Cracking your skull.
He advances on her.

And he's on her. With his left arm he brutally forces her her knees as his right hand, palm out and fingers splayed clamp themselves over her face. God loves you, Mary!
Katherine brings the tire iron down on his skull with all her might, DRIVING him to the floor. She turns to Grey Ho her eyes wild.
Finish it.
He, everyone, just stare. Stunned to stone.
Finish it!

Grey Horse timidly picks up his prayer stick and with a v faltering and cracked, in the insane glare of the wrecked pickup's headlights, resumes the Enemy Ghost Way chant. Katherine turns back to Gabriel.
Go home.

She HITS him again with the tire iron. Then lifts it high once more above her head. She's going to crush him, to im his skull. When a hand stops her. Sort of a hand. A claw. Lucifer's. He's standing behind h holding the raised bar still.
No.
Katherine releases the bar and lets it clang to the floor Lucifer turns to the villagers, gazing fearfully at him a they awkwardly try to finish the chant.
Please. Go on.
Lucifer's gaze falls on a deeply fucked-up Gabriel who gr at the sight of him.
Oh man, this just isn't my day.
Lucifer kneels down beside him. Katherine instinctively s to reach for the tire iron but the sycophant hisses a liq chattering warning at her.
Long time.
The world's young, man.
And full of ambition.
This isn't your war.
But I remember the last one. Michael's  war.
You lost.
But lots of angels were with me.  every one followed their leader out  of heaven.
Yeah yeah, I was there, remember?

Except one. Oh, he was with me all  right. He hated the Eagle Scout.  Envied the power He gave to His Son.  But this angel never came out front  during the war. And when it ended he  thought maybe, maybe the Eagle Scout  didn't notice. So he laid low and  towed the company line till he could  start his own war. It was all just  jealousy.
You're dreaming.
But maybe He did notice. Maybe that's  why I'm here.
-- Stay away from me.
You've always been a part of me,  Gabriel. And now it's time to come  home.
Fuck you!

Lucifer slams Gabriel's head against the floor and pins i As the angel thrashes furiously, Lucifer FORCES his arm i Gabriel's chest. Gabriel cries out as Lucifer PULLS his a half out and FORCES it deeper. Again. And again. Soon  Gabriel's screams become giggles, then a crazed, hysteric laughter. The room goes insane. An impossible nightmare of chanting Navahos, glaring headlights, and Gabriel's echoing laught as Lucifer pumps his chest. Laughter that rises to a kind orgasmic cry then instantly stops as Lucifer pulls out th angel's heart, And eats it. At that instant Grey Horse places his hand on Mary's fore speaks a last line, and the chant is completed. Sticky, smoky, awful silence. Gabriel is a non-thing. A  battered, hollow shell. Bartholomew Grey Horse, his voice cracked and finished, t to Katherine.
The enemy spirit is gone.
(weak, faint) Where?

From outside the kiva suddenly comes the sound of a wound savage GROWL. Katherine walks to the doorway. Just outsid lone coyote is twisting in the dirt with furious agony.  Abruptly its thrashings cease. The animal stands and flas for an instant at Katherine cold yellow eyes more than an Then it's gone into the blackness. Forever. She turns and goes back to Thomas in the cab. Bleeding to death is a real possibility for him. She pulls an old shi out of the back and tries to makeshift a wrap for his sli arm.
More will come... To look for the  soul...
And they won't find it. Not in Mary.
A few of the village elders appear at the cab.
Can you help him?
We have some bandages.
Katherine walks over to where Mary, sweaty and shaken, si huddled in a corner attended by Grey Horse.
Are you all right, pumpkin?
Mary's voice shakes as tears roll out her eyes.
I'm okay.
Katherine gathers her up into her arms and holds her.
It's going to be okay... We're all  going to be okay...
The chattering, hissing sycophant grabs Gabriel's body by the hair and shoulders and drags it out the door. Lucifer has remained behind, crouched on his haunches, his liquid yellow eyes on Katherine.
I can't quite bring myself to say  thank you.
I understand.
Then this is done.
Not necessarily. Maybe I like you.  Maybe I want you to come with me.
He rises to his feet and steps slowly toward her.
You owe me, Katherine. And you're  going to ask me to take you home.
(clutching Mary) No.
You will. You will because any other  way is going to be more awful than  you can imagine.
Are you threatening me?
Just a grinning, twisted stare.

Then you've picked the wrong person  this time. I've just about had it up  to here with ghosts. So you can put  away the horror movie sneer and the  K-Mart halloween eyes, because we  know you now. We know you all. And  if you want to force the issue then  go ahead because you're just another  angel to me. Take a look at your  buddy Gabriel. Then ask yourself, do  you really, really want to fuck with  us?
The smallest hint of a pause.
Perhaps another time.
I'm holding my breath.
Goodbye, Katherine. For now.
And he's gone. Through the door and into the night.
Is he coming back?
I don't think so, honey... I don't  think so...

The fullness of day over Old Woman Butte, hot and bright. Chasing the night and its fears away under the punishing  glare of noon. The village is full of police vehicles now. Green broncos from the Navaho Tribal Police. Blue and white sheriff  department sedans. The Navaho cops are talking with Katherine and Mary. Thom is sitting on the trunk of a patrol car getting his wound properly bandaged as the Sheriff we met earlier leans bes him chewing on a wild oat stalk.
(to deputy bandaging  Thomas) Is he going to live?
With any luck.
(to Thomas) I thought I told you to give me a  call if anything snarled.
There wasn't a phone.
Hmmm.
He chews some more on his stalk. Looks off at the village
This fella, Gabriel...
Yeah.
Gabriel what?
Just Gabriel.
Pretty violent guy, Gabriel. Even  for out here.
Yeah.
Caught up with him at the village?
He caught up with me.
What were you doing way up here?
Enemy Ghost Way for Mary Tsosie.
Indian stuff.
Yeah. Indian stuff.
The Sheriff looks over at Katherine's pickup still jammed into the side of the kiva.
Did you kill this Gabriel?
Maybe. I think so.
Don't have any idea where the body  is I suppose.
No.
Well, if he's alive he won't get far  out there. Us or the coyotes, it'll  be the same. (beat) I rang your office in LA. They don't  have a warrant out for a Gabriel. Or  anybody else in Arizona.
I hadn't gotten around to it.
Sort of an out of pocket thing.
Yes.
The Sheriff takes his hat off. Runs his finger along the  inside band.
That woman lying at the bottom of  the arroyo, the one still in her  hospital gown, know anything about  that?
No.
Really.
Really.
This Gabriel was sure one busy dude.
Yes, he was.
Beat.
You'll be going back to Los Angeles  now?
Yeah.
The Sheriff pushes off from the patrol car and tosses asi the oak stalk.
Don't hurry back.
The deputy finishes his bandaging.
Don't do much but breathe the next  few days. And get to a hospital.  You're going to need some serious  stitches.
Thanks.
Say hi to Hollywood for me.
He follows his boss. Katherine and Mary walk up.
You look bad.
Thank you. I feel worse. (to Katherine re Navaho  cops) They lean on you much?
Not really. I think they might have  even understood. One of them's related  to this clan. He'll give us a ride  back if we want.
Good. I think I've about run out of  hospitality with the sheriff's  department.
The moment drifts into silence.
Do you think it's really over?
Till we die.
Her eyes settle on his.
When I die, I want you with me.
I want that too.
She touches his cheek, Mary cradled between them.

Thomas sitting in the back of the tribal police bronco,  looking out the window to the shimmering sands; red and y and black. To clouds brewing over faraway forgotten mount To the end of the earth. As the bronco drifts away from us toward the empty, rocky horizon, as it slowly blends and is consumed by the land,
